2012 bottle from the CoOP. Aroma and flavor is mostly consistent with the Brandy version, but this one isn't quite as hot. Bourbon mixes better with the barley wine to bring out the carmel, bubble gum, and toasted coconut. Still rather hot, but great flavor and a great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bouteille de 375 ml, avec bouchon de liège, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Le contenu est flat. Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel et dalcool. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe dalcool et de vanille. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de vanille en arrière goût. (Rating #4720)

Incredible aroma with a dark brown pour, sweet but balanced taste and subtle, warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours a wonderful dark brown. Aroma is tons of bourbon,  caramel and more bourbon.  Flavor is strong bourbon,  nice barley wine and finishes nicely with a little booze. Awesome beer.

2012 vintage. Pours a deep brown--almost the shade of a deep apple cider. No head whatsoever. The aroma is fantastic! Smells of bourbon, malt and some fruits. The taste is out of this world! Immediately one of the best beers Ive had and without a doubt the best barley wine Ive had. Perfect blend of bourbon, malts, and a slight bitter fruit aftertaste. The palate is much the same. Absolutely flawless notes ranging from sweet bourbon up front, malts and oak in the middle, with a slight fruit bitter finish. Absolutely wonderful!
Poured with no head. 2011. Appearance is lackluster, but shouldnt matter. Aroma is fantastic, whiskey, oak, and molasses. Would take this over any whiskey.

Trade from jrgratz. Thanks!!! 2011 dated bottle. Pours dark brown with ruby edges and no head whatsoever. Smell is strong vanilla, oak, molasses, and lots of bourbon. Thick and viscous mouthfeel with essentially no carbonation. Flavor is big vanilla notes with sweet molasses and brown sugar, finishing with big whiskey notes. Some mellow burnt charcoal taste too that is new to me and relaxing like sittin by the fire. Lots of alcohol warmth. Some real astringent alcohol. A sipper for sure, but an awesome sipper.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2014 2011 bottle. Burgundy light brown colour - pretty! Aroma is bourbon barrel and vanilla. Wow! Taste is booze first, then caramel, big vanilla and heat. So tasty and surprising! Palate is vanilla caramel with the bourbon aging. Yum! Overall, brilliant! The flavours are everything I love, all in balance. One to hunt down and savour slowly.

Bottle 375 ml, 2012 vintage. Cork opens with a little fizz. Pours alomst black with a two finger high head. Great aroma, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, chocolate. Boozy but creamy, full bodied, medium carbonation. Long finish, oak, dried fruit, alcohol, vanilla. A few years since I last had this beer, its as good, maybe even better than I remember
One finger head, fully diminishing, little to no carbonation, sweet bourbon aroma, woody aroma, boozy finish.  I like this but wish I had one that I could have aged for a year more.

A - pours dead flat thick murky cola with absolutely zero head. Nice legs. S - fantastic barrel aged aromas. Bourbon, Graham crackers, vanilla, dark fruits( raisins prunes). All up front. Ripe banana, biscuity notes, spices (cinnamon and nutmeg) dry charred oak, alcohol. Complex and rich bourbon goodness. M - zero carb, watery right up front, to a full bodied rich palette. Strong booze. You can actually literally taste the bourbon. T - rhubarb, graham crackers, vanilla, toffee, caramelized sugars, and bourbon. Over ripe banana, oak, subtle dried fruits, and light grains. Long sweet bourbon alcohol warmed end. Lingering sweet vegetal notes. O -  amazing aroma, disappointing zero carbonation, overly boozy. Good but not great.  3.9

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottle [Bourbon 2012 stamp on neck]. Hazy dark brown colour with small, frothy, diminishing, beige head, leaving a thin layer. Aroma has explicit bourbon notes, vanilla, leather, oak etc. Taste is moderately sweet, lots of caramel, toffee, vanilla. Very well balanced, smooth, silk, soft. Sadly the bourbon flavours predominate the underlying genuine beer aroma, whereas they perfectly fit in taste. Outstanding beer.

Perfect beer to celebrate the return of my family. Been looking forward to this for awhile, and more so hoping its not infected or flat. 2010 vintage poured into Firestone Walker tulip from a. 375 mL bottle. 

This is not a pretty beer. Murky brown with absolutely no carbonation. Thankfully this is Angels Shares worst quality. 

Recovery from an underwhelming look is quick. Aroma is stellar. Ive not encountered a better smelling barleywine than this one. Rich as rich can be. Cut vanilla bean, graham cracker, aged bourbon, still present booze, charred oak, sweet salted caramel. Its absolutely decadent, and I havent had a sip.

Taste is good, but not on par with smell. All the appeal of a standard setting English barleywine are present, including sweet caramel malt, cotton candy, and prominent alcohol. Additionally, I readily taste bourbon, white grape, red apple, slight red pepper, strong vanilla, and a hint of aged brandy. Very complex and thoroughly enjoyable. 

Mouthfeel is so-so. While the body is great, the complete absence of carbonation mars the overall experience. A few bubbles would make this beer significantly better. 

In the end this is still a fantastic beer. I will buy again on the hope it might have carbonation. The recipe is nearly flawless, so kudos to LA for concocting such a great tasting beer.

Bottle 37.5cl from Allen many thanks, a deep oily dark beer with low head. Nose is intense on wood notes, vanilla, caramel, fig, prunes, caramel. Aroma is on caramel, barley sugar, chocolate malt, fig, vanilla, prunes, raisin, creamy body, not too sweet, complex body. Finish is on wood, chocolate and vanilla again, long duration, very nice.
Glassflaske fra esp0r, drukket på hytta. Køl svart farge.ingen skum eller karbonering. Heftig smak av rødvin,eik,vanilje. Dette er helt på grensen til hva øl er
Shared a bottle after quite a few imperial stouts.  Strong bourbon aged flavoring here.

Draft at Jerrys barrel event. Dark mahogany with scant, tan head / Nose of fresh caramel, dark fruit, liquor barrel, chocolate, and vanilla / Full body, thick and chewy, some heat, sweet with excellent balance and lingering, bitter finish lurking underneath / Flavors of fresh caramel, raisins, prunes, cocoa, coconut, vanilla, and bourbon barrel / What a nitpicker - .1 point deduction for heat.

Bottle 375ml.
Some "pop" at opening. Pours brown with no head. Aroma is of alcohol, chocolate, bourbon, roasted malt. Taste is of alcohol, roasted malt, sligth acidity, bourbon. Palate: Full bodied, nice creamy texture. Overall: Pretty good.
Big and boozey with a strong bourbon flavor. If you like a strong alcohol flavor you will like this beer.

Bottle (375 ml). Traded by reynolds314, thanks Matt! Dark brown with ruby reflects and almost no head. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak, alcohol and dark fruits. Taste is about the same but a little less intense. Sirupy. Full bodied. Low carbonation (not flat). Warming alcohol. Very good and complex bourbon barrel Barley Wine and nice sipper. The bourbon is present but not overwhelming, well done!

29/01/2013 Brasserie 4:20 (12.7oz, 2008 vintage bottle). Miele di castagno, intensa, riflessi bordeaux, schiuma assente. Al naso sentori di vaniglia, note di ciliegie e di vino fortificato, una netta nota acetica che pian piano prende il sopravvento su tutto. In bocca è disastrosa, acetica, sempre di più col passare del tempo, legnosa e astringente, asfalta il palato. Corpo pieno, carbonazione quasi assente. Peccato averla provata in condizioni pessime.

375 ml. bottle.  Thanks GT!  Pours a reddish brown with the smallest of head.  Aroma of dark fruit, bourbon, wood, and vanilla.  Taste is bourbon, dark cherries, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, and wood.  Rich and smooth. A delight to sip.
An awesome taste, incredible mix of flavor, alcooloc but dry. The flaver is very persistent.

Pours dark dark brown with no head
Shabaam! Knockout aroma... Cocoa, vanilla, figs, raisins, hints of alcohol. Aroma heaven!!!
Vanilla bomb, hints of cocoa, chocolate, brown sugar
Low to no carbonation. Medium bodied, medium creamy. More port wine than barley wine w.r.t carbonation. Really weird to drink a BW that feels like a IS.

2012 bottle.  Cola like body with a nice off white head that disappeared quickly.  Raisin, sherry, oak, vanilla, nuts, licorice, wet leather, soil.  Heavy big body but surprisingly smooth with nice slight carbonation.  Like an aged whiskey.  Very nice.
From a 12.7 oz bottle shared at home.  Bottled in 2012.  Pours a murky dark brown with a thin off white head.  B bourbon and prunes in the nose.  Raisins, plums and vanilla notes.  Wow!

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of dark bread, dark chocolate and mild coffee, moderate hop and yeast notes of resin, herbs, beef broth and dried mushroom, with background notes of raisin, maple syrup, alcohol, licorice and fresh mint. Head is non existent but has good legs. Color is muddy dark brown. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately bittersweet and lightly acidic. Palate is full, syrupy with a soft carbonation and has a moderate to heavy alcoholic and a little sticky finish. This beer hangs somewhere between a Barley Wine and a an English Stout, everything about it is rich and bold. I didnt want it to end.

From notes: Poured hazy, opaque chocolate brown-to-black with a small light tan head.  Chocolatey aroma with notes of wood and vanilla mixed in.  Full body, perhaps a touch on the lighter side of that.  Oily mouthfeel with a mildly boozy, astringent finish.  Flavor was malty sweet with woody notes beneath.  As it warms, the alcohol blends nicely with the more prominent wood notes.  noted a smokoy, sweet note in the finish.
bottle 2009. pours light black/dark brown with zip zero head. big boozey aroma some vanilla. taste is sweet caramel chocolate and bourbon. would be much better with some carbonation

Damn. Talking about a beer that meets expectations. Rich and full bodied. I savored every sip. Sweet and to the point. Alcohol is hidden like it isnt even there. Rich toffee, caramel, bourbon, candy. Like I said it was sweet, but never cloying. Superb.

Bottle. Opaque deep brown liquid with minimal off - white head. Aroma coconut, wood, dark fruit, toffee, vanilla, buttery bourbon and soy. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of toffee, raw sugar, raisins, vanilla and wood. Medium bodied with low or no carbonation. Very nice stuff, complex.

Bottle at ÖÖWF cons 2012-11-17 Örebro
AR: bourbon, Thai vanilla
AP: watery pitch black, wee head
F: sugary,bourbon, warm milk,dark chocolate, coffee, kokos boll, wee grainy, peppery

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2013 Bottled 2012.
Appearance: The body is a murky brown thats opaque through the center, no head at all, only a very thin ring.
Aroma: The aroma is a bit musky with dark fruits that is rather strong, oak is also prominent with a light alcohol presence and perhaps some molasses.
Taste: The oak is pretty strong here right away with lots of wood presence, theres a musky raisin fruit throughout and the finish is pretty strong of bourbon becoming dry with a light burn on the finish. Not really a fan of this.
Palate: Thick, but at the same time a bit thin, just a very little amount of carbonation.
Overall: This is a pretty big disappointment to me, theres nothing here that I love about this, its just okay. I dont care to seek this out again.
2013 Vintage.
Appearance: The body is black with deep mahogany through the edges, the head is dense with great retention, slowly settling into a dense brown coating.
Aroma: The aroma is strong of bourbon and oak right away, but  brown sugar and caramel back it with hints of milk chocolate and even some roasted malts. The aroma is restrained though, perhaps some coconut?
Taste: Coconut is prominent right away and becomes a strong persistent flavor throughout, all the way to the finish where it lingers for a bit. Backing the coconut is light caramel and brown sugar and bourbon on the mid-taste, the bourbon persists through the finish with a lingering spicy kick to it. Certainly heavy on coconut though.
Palate: Creamy and thick.
Overall: This is good, but not $15 for a 375ml good, especially when Sucaba exists. I am kicking myself for spending $15 again on this, but at least this was carbonated.

Bottle. Pour is a dark amber with no head. The aroma is really sweet with a lot of caramel. The taste is super smooth. Get a lot of bourbon, but so smooth. Finishes smooth as can be. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of nuts and bourbon. Taste is caramel, brown sugar and booze. It coats the mouth with a hot alcohol blanket, hidden but with a definite presence. It is a sipper, but definitely balanced as it is never cloying. My only reference to this experience is the Benelux Grande Armada and this one is definitely .3-.4 over it! Yum!

Draft at the Toronado Barley Wine Fest, or could have been a bottle or three.   Much fun and much heat, huge beer.    That raisin, choc, coconut and intense fruity finish is insane.      Good memories, I think.  Hic.
Sample @ SBWF 12. Dark brown colour with a small tan head. Aroma of fruit, chocolate. Flavour is like the aroma but with some vanilla to it.

Sampled at SBWF11
Murky magogny flavour. No head.
Oaky whisky all along with a slightly harsh bitterness with notes of cocoa-powder.

375ml C&C bottle, 2010 vintage.  Pours a deep, dark brown color with no head. No bubbles.  Flat.  Aroma is bourbon, malt, maybe a little smokey.  Heavy on the palate with zero carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, vanilla, oak, bourbon, caramel, toffee, a nice bit of alcohol warmth, with a very smooth, bourbon finish.  Disappointing.  This would be a top ten beer for if it were carbonated. Will try to rate again.  Hopefully everything will be the same, but with bubbles.

2011 version, 12.7 oz C&C bottle served in a DFH signature glass.

A: Whoa, carbonation! Not just from the etching on the bottom of the glass, but there were lots of bubbles and a thin light tan head actually formed on the pour. That subsided quickly leaving a pretty still dark brown, cola looking body with a thin ring around the rim. Some splotchy lace is left down the glass.

S: Smells of bourbon, oak, dark pitted fruits and some subtle sweetness all fill the nose.

T: Big bourbon up front that lingers throughout the whole sip. As it develops in the mouth the oak comes through as well as a caramel like sweetness. Some dried fruits, mainly figs and dates, also pop up in the taste. There is some definite heat in there, but it is far from from overpowering.

M: Heavy bodied, slightly chewy in nature with some actually prickly carbonation. Im psyched. A little heat and some subtle sweetness left on the palate. As the beer warms the carbonation goes by the wayside, but it doesnt hurt the beer.

O: Well this gets major points because its actually somewhat carbonated. The bourbon flavor is bold and lingers throughout the whole sip, but still is pretty tasty. This is definitely a sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-05-2011

Holy crap, was my initial impression after a single magnificent sip.  Ive grown so sick of Imperial Stouts and IPAs, I know that sounds crazy, but its true, all the top beers seem to fall in that category.  This was such a shock, I cant even explain how amazing my first sip was, it was like I fell into a pit of butterscotch and alcohol.  Beautiful aroma, amazing taste, strong alcohol flavor at the end that somehow manages to compliment the beer.  Absolutely phenomenal, my favorite so far.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2014 Pours dark brown, almost black. No head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, corinthians, chocolate, dark berries, port. Just amazing! Taste is equally fantastic. Looong, sweet opening with roasted malt, toffee, vanilla, before a slight hoppiness leads into a long alcohol and port finish. Creamy, oily, thick body. Bottles aged for three to four years have had very low carbonation, whereas fresher bottles have been fairly rich in carbonation. Any way you have it, its an absolutely amazing beer!

Bottle pours cloudy, deep brown color, no foam. Powerful nose, alcohol is evident, bourbon, caramel, hazelnut, raisin. Woof. This is probably the most whiskey-like beer i have had in recent memory. Alcohol up front, chocolate, almond or hazelnut, fades to coffee bitterness. Strong, complex, not a daily drinker though.

Bottle, pours a dark, murky brown with the perfect about of carbonation.  Fantastic the aroma bourbon, vanilla, molasses, and oak. Taste is very complex: bourbon, chocolate and some dark fruits.   Glad I didnt run into one of the bad bottles.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks little brother Erez and sis-in-law Shira for choosing, buying and delivering this one! Opaque muddy brown with no head, very alcoholic aroma, then childrens non-alcoholic wine and very velvety. Tastes deep, sweet, slightly alcoholic, chocolatey and cherry. Smooth liquor texture, full body. Really good.

Bottle @ THE Barley Wine Tasting. Cheers to Leighton for bringing this along. The appearance is deep brown with a small  white head. The nose is big bourbon, sugary vanilla, plenty of fresh wood.  The taste is strong bourbon flavors, jammy cherry malts, plenty of cocoa and toffee. Big body, soft carbonation. A very nice sipper that I finished far too quickly! Pretty great.

Dark brown pour, no real head at all more like a leggy wine.  Rich super sweet aroma (this doesnt smell anything like a barley wine) starts with vanilla, almost maple syrup, hints of oak, then that subdues a bit and I get a lightly hot alcohol, a touch of nuttiness and a light hint of cocoa.  Huge rich palate thick and sticky and stays on my tongue for a while after a sip.  Flavor is super sweet rich rich rich lots of syrupy sweetness clearly picking up some of the heaven hill, almost a smoothed down version of it to be honest.  Vanilla and oak notes, a tiny hit of chocolate in the back and alcohol clearly present in the swallow.  A very good beer, but clearly not a BW and more whiskey from the barrel than the base beer, a lot of its character is lost (if it had one) but again still a great drink.

Bottle sample.
Murky dark brown color with a minimal head.
Aroma of chocolate liquor, dark cherries and cocoa.
Flavor is full of chocolate covered cherries, with roasted malts and port notes.
Full body, low carbonation, super long finish, very good beer.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks kerenmk. Murky brown with no head. Powerful aroma of chocolate, bourbon, oak, dark fruits, nutty notes and a bit of alcohol. Sweet malty flavor with chocolate, bourbon, liqueur, some dark fruitiness, wood spiciness and some alcohol. Full-bodied. A good one.
What an awesome beer. Ever tried a barley wine with beannies and weenies? Seriously! It kicks ass. Who woulda thunk it? Just shut up and try it. Now.

A: Oak, vanilla, caramel malt, mollasses, and bourbon. P: Dark brown, thin head. T: Bourbon, caramel, alcohol, a hint of vanilla and soy sauce. Finishes with heat. M: thin w/ carbonation. O: A good beer with a nice presentation of barrel.
OMG! It is incredible. I aged it 4 years in my cellar. It has a nice bourbon  red wine flavor with vanilla and oak.

Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival 2011. Dark brown beer with almost no head. Licorice, tar, vanilla, dark cocolate and bourbon aroma. Licorice, vanilla, caramell, dark chocolate, bourbon and raisins flavour. I love this kind of beers :-)
Color is motor oil. With no head. Aroma is strong kinda barelywine aroma. Taste is dark fruit. Kinda pick up raiseins and figs.
Bottle pours dark brown not much head. Smells tastes bourbon dark fruit caramel. Pretty much stroung booze taste could use time to mellow out. Still great beer.
very strong alcohol aftertaste (a little to much for my liking), very strong but not the best I have had.

At the brewery. Pours a dark brown with red highlights. Foam is a light tan, but only is visible around the edges. Aroma is sherry, dark fruit, and a little bourbon. Bourbon is highly noticeable on the tongue (which I like). Cherries, toffee, and just a bit of oak. Finish is fruity and dry. Cleans up nicely with the alcohol and leaves the cherries as a burnt offering.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2012 Had on tap. Great beer. Lots of flavor shines through that i missed on the regular version. The bourbon flavors complement the malt bill really well.

Bottle - 2011 vintage,
Near black pour, very little head.  Nose is decadent - bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, toffee.  Crazy complex.  Tons of barrel aged flavor - vanilla, wood, bourbon.  Very nice.

Draught at Lost Abbey. Nose of vanilla, cherry, bourbor, port, chocolate, caramel. A bit too much bourbon maybe. Flavor of caramel/toffee, vanilla, bourbon, raisins, chocolate. Wow. Big flavorover the top sweetness but luscious.

Bottle into snifter. Pour is dark dark brown with virtually no head and tan lacing. Aromas are big bourbon and vanilla notes with some cocoa and molasses in there. Very rich aroma. Taste follows suit with tons of booze and vanilla flavors, but with a rich caramel and cocoa finish. Syrupy texture. Very good but very rich. Im glad this comes in small bottles.

Bottle
Appearance - Cloudy brown, no head, little carbonation
Aroma - Cherries, wood, vanilla, molasses, chestnuts
Taste - Warm, big bourbon and oak flavours, vanilla

I cant thank OmegaX enough for this beer! This brew was big and sweet in a boozy sense. Lots of sweet bourbon and licorice are among smooth malty undertones. Delectable and quite the sipper.

Draft: pours an a dark brown with a small tan head. The aroma is dark fruit and cocoa. The taste is rich with a little alcohol warmth. Malt is dominant with the cocoa.  Bourbon notes linger on the finish. The mouthfeel is perfect with a medium to heavy character.  Overall this is a very good beer and better than recent examples Ive tasted. Very enjoyable.
pours a merky chocolate brown color, with 0 head.  instantly reminded me of deliverance, malty with a slight cocoa flavor and a warm ending of alcohol.  AMAZING

Draft at Khyber Pass (though have had many times in the past.) Pours jet black with a slim tan head. The bourbon version is the best of the bunch. A big step above the original (which is already a tremendous brew!) Huge dark notes with a creamy smooth texture. Rich bourbon flavors. Notes of charcoal. Leather. French roast coffee. Belgium chocolate. Burnt marshmallow. Nutella. Some juicy red fruits hiding under the deep dark waves. Flavors are perfectly blended. Thick full body. Warms to a spicy vanilla caramel. Certainly something to sip and savor, though a very smooth finish. Not afraid to give this one of my highest ratings. One of my favorite beers ever for many years! Wonderful!

Bottle from 2010. Pours jet black with little to no head. Nose is bourbon, black malt, molasses and bittersweet chocolate. First sip is sweet candi sugar, with coffee, roasted malt and booze. Finish is thin with little mouth feels but nice overtones of coffee biterness.
Murky brown with a tiny head. The nose is amazing here. Layered bourbon, raisin and tobacco. Full bodied with slight, but present carbonation. Wildly complex and delicious.

thanks to Jason for bringing this 2008 bottle (i think it was 2008). poured deep black and rather thick, i had a trace of carbonation but overall it was hard to find. giant scents of bourbon mainly with alcohol and chocolate behind it. mainly bourbon. there were faint hints of chocolate, some light vanilla, and maybe some oak. there was some serious heat on this, so alcohol dominated and as it warmed, it was even more dominant.  mainly a syrupy feel however there was a burning and warming sensation from the booze. the top of my tongue suffered as well as my stomach. this was a very slow sipper. i was not getting as much burn as others. this was very good although it needs more time to mellow and allow the flavors to blend together. there was far too much bourbon in this that it took away from everything else. i can imagine another year+, this would be amazing. Reviewed on: 08-02-2009

Lost Abbey Angels Share Bourbon Barrel. Tap at Raglan in OB. No idea how I havent rated this yet. Either way, I quick and dirty rating follows. Murky brown with a one finger beige head, creamy and stayed as a thick ring and film for the duration. Bourbon, old wood, tobacco, toffee, sweet caramel, raisins and brown sugar, decaying leaves. Good amount of tasty oxidation. Flavor follows, nice and boozy to help dry out all the sweetness--never got close to cloying. Semi dryish old wood bourbon finish, alcohol present, but not 12.5% strong, bitterness peaked at a 2-3. Big full body, low carbonation. Excellent. Dunno which version I prefer. 9-4-9-4-17--4.3
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Shared by esp0r last christmas..
Dark brown, almost no head.
sweet malty bourbon aroma, dark fruits, nuts
Malty taste with alcohol, caramel and raisins. Thick good body, low carbonated. Warm bitter finish that last a good long time.

Bottle shared by Dreadnaught33. Thanks Jonathan!

The beer has a color similar to that of a cup of coffee or perhaps cola. There is very little head that leaves absolutely no lacing. The aroma is bold and powerful. Caramels and butterscotch candies soaked in bourbon over a strong malt bill. The taste is very bold and enjoyable. The feel would be great if this beer was adequately carbonated. I would definitely drink this again.

***

2008 vintage

Carbonation was perfect. Similar flavor. Still some heat, but delicious.
4/4.5/4.5/4/4 or 4.5

Pours an ominous black with a slight edge of ruby clarity. The finger of off-white head is short lived but even without hardly any retention, there is some pretty impressive lacing and some sexy legs.

Nose is pretty damn boozy... some fresh tequila notes surface immediately. Sweet caramel and hot citrus. More tequila... was this aged in a tequila barrel? Seriously, Im getting all sorts of tequila notes. Sweet booze, some leather and obvious wood. Im intrigued.

Mmm... I was afraid of more tequila, not the case. Hot bourbon, rich woods, strong vanilla bits, some of that leather, plenty of heat that somehow doesnt inhibit the other flavors. Very interesting stuff. Like a bourbon/beer hybrid... tasty.

Very glad to have had the chance to try this one. Unique, warming, and not entirely flat!

2012 Release. On tap at Lost Abbey. Nose is all dominant bourbon and oak. Very dark brown. Taste is slightly malty, but mostly bourbon and oak. Im interested to see how this cellars as the malt bill tastes perfectly made for enhancing the bourbon character.
small cork and cage bottle courtesy of John, popping the cork lets loose a nice sound, and beneath was a carbonated non infected treat full of vanilla and dark fruit, oily in the taste.

On tap @ Capones.  Poured a deep dark velvety brown with a medium sized tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is bourbon, plum, dark chocolate, and hint of vanilla oak.  Taste is caramel malt, tart cherry, bourbon, vanilla, and raisin.  Pleasant alcohol warming on the finish.
Almost completely flat, but not infected. Lots ofSugars, vanilla, oak, licorice.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Very dark pour with a cream head. Killer oak and bourbon nose and taste. Slick palate. One of the best beers Ive ever had!

The aroma is sweet bourbon, chocolate, soy sauce, dark ripened fruit.  The apperance is deep brown, almost black, with a tan head which dissipates quickly.  Low carbonation.  The flavor is sweet bourbon, vanilla, oaky, dark fruits.  The finish is again bourbon, booze burn.  Followed by a light sweetness, and pine needles.  Nice thick, oily body.  Excellent.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with an off white head. Big boozy bourbon aroma with dark fruity and malty notes. The flavor has a dark fruity and malty sweetness, with vanilla. Good stuff.

I dont normally love Barrel-Aged Barleywines, but when I do, I prefer Bourbon Angels Share.  Had on draft at Monks during Philly Beer Week two years ago; also on several other occasions in bottles at various tastings and releases.  As long as its carbonated and not infected, this beer is just so delightful, lots of smooth caramel malty flavors and sweet cherry with a bourbon kick that rounds everything off nicely.  Docked a few points for inconsistency, though.

At: vanilla, extremely rich, like nothing Ive felt before, port Wine, raisins, oak, alcohol is evident, but not boozy, prunes, dark fruit, jam and honey. 
Ap: colour is black, no head.
F: Whiskey up front, lots and lots of bourbon, vanilla, spicy, acidic, very rich, but the bourbon overpowers the flavours from the beer itself, alcohol is very evident and it is very boozy all the way through, notes of port and chocolate and coffee. In my opinion the flavours are not balanced, there are lots and lots of interesting flavours, but they are not in harmony and the booziness and bourbon flavours are so distinct and powerful that you struggle to find the other notes. Given time you find very complex flavours beneath the initial blast.
M: Very thick mouthfeel almost no carbonation. 
T: This is a real experience, very cool to have tried, demanding, not balanced, but When you wrap your head around it, it delivers!

Dark brown in color with very little head and decent legs. Aroma is heavy in bourbon with oak, lots of vanilla, toffee, light raostiness, and caramel. Taste is of bourbon. wood, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar and toffee.

Hard Liver. Dark brown/black, tan head. Wow I did not know this beer was this dark. Aroma of molasses, dark fruit, some soy and tobacco, leather. Taste has a slight earthy bitterness, lots of malt/dark fruit sweetness, nice bourbon taste.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Cerveza oscura de baja carbonatación y espuma. Gran aroma y sabor a bourbon, que es el protagonista de esta cerveza.

On tap in a chalice at the Watering Hole. A dark, murky brown color with almost no head. Bourbon dominates the aroma with some fruitiness (raisins and perhaps a hint of pears). Extremely boozy, bourbon forward, so much so that the bourbon hides much of the barley wine characteristics. It has a medium body with a slightly slick texture. Overall, a great barrel-aged barley wine, but I think it needs to age awhile to mellow out the bourbon and bring out its true awesomeness.

Poured with vigor to the glass, this brew yielded no head at all with zero lacing. 
The color is a deep murky brown with slights hints of red in the hue. The aroma is wonderful, chocolate, molasses, vanilla, caramel, sweet dark fruit, malt, and a very small amount of booze. 
Taste, vanilla, some sweet plumb, roasted malt, and fig. I find a lot more booze in the taste than I did in the nose, but still pretty well balanced. The mouth feel is pretty interesting... No carbonation at all. It has a light syrupy feel, but also has the same cloudy tongue coating texture you get from a strong cup of cuban espresso that is starting to cool down. It defiantly has some warming to it as well

2011 bottle.  Dark brown pour with only a small tinge of carbonation visible.  Aroma was big time booze, bourbon, lots of caramel, vanilla and oak.  Flavors were actually not as in your face.  Lots of caramel, bourbon, notes of vanilla and wood, not as sweet as one would think going in.  Nice bittersweet finish, lots going on here.  Carbonation was very soft, mouthfeel slick and oily.  Extremely drinkable, AKA dangerous.

At 2012 Avery Strong Ale Fest.  Black with a thin light tan head. Aroma of vanilla oak, bourbony, with a heavy roasty dark chocolate tone, and slight cold coffee. Taste is amazing with a dark sweet chocolatyness, boozy bourbon, oak and vanilla undertones. But its just a little too warm.

Dark brown, very small creamy beige head. Both aroma and taste are fantastic! Whiskey, vanilla and wood! Top beer!!! Oily texture.

2010 bottle. Aroma is huge wood, bourbon, vanilla, sweet malts, huge. Flavour is huge vanilla, wood, roasty and caramel malts, quite alcoholic yet still smooth. Bourbon is a bit over the top but still an amazing beer.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 Black, no head. Very mature aroma, concentrated fruit, big sweetness, some roasted nuts. Fantastic aroma. Sticky smooth body. Rich alcohol, too big on bourbon. Sharp. Does have a long aftertaste. (At the De Molen tasting)

Bottle at monthly tasting session @ De Molen, hosted by dEnk. Black pour, no head. Aroma is leathery bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, coffee and caramel. Flavor is huge bourbon, very full, heavy vanilla and leathery. A bit too much, but still very nice.

Sample at de molen
No head deep ruby pour.  Vanilla and figs.  Yummy smooth beer.  Excellent

From notes.  First reviewed 11/17/2011.  Served on tap in a tulip at Hopleaf.

My pour is a totally opaque mahogany color, with a few spots of ruby or burgundy in the corners of the glass. A modest tan head melts away over the first half of the glass, not bothering to leave any lace. It is noticeably viscous as I swirl it in my glass.

The aroma is outstanding; a true wake up call after drinking a few milder beers. A complex spectrum of sweet aromas just burst out of the glass. The bourbon is noticeable, more so in the nose than in the flavor, with figs, dates, and raisins providing the fruit notes. Sweet toffee, caramel, and dark chocolate fudge overwhelm the milder bready malt notes. This is close to perfect.

The flavor starts strong as well, and each component is so well-integrated it takes me a few sips to distinguish each one. Dark gooey caramel, a bit of molasses, and some dark Belgian chocolate provide a sweet candy front, dark caramel and lightly roasted malt feed off the sweetness and add more depth. A blast of figs and rum raisin come in and lead to the ridiculous depth to the flavor. A light bourbon note overlays the rest of the sip, which is comprised of oak, a generous amount of vanilla, some coconut, and a few more dark fruit flavors. The finish is mostly sweet, with just a touch of bitterness and alcohol to keep the sweetness in check. 

To call this anything less than full bodied would be blasphemy. There is no doubt about the intention of this beer - a full bodied, creamy, sweet, and complex brew, and the mouthfeel is consistent with this goal. Smooth and creamy for sure, it is a little syrupy at times, which is the only reason for the less than perfect score. It is properly carbonated, but the carbonation is hardly noticeable given everything else that is going on here.

This is a beer that borders on greatness. I had a less than stellar experience with a flat Brandy Angels Share bottle, but the difference is like night and day. From the moment I had my first whiff of it, I knew this was going to be a special beer. The bourbon treatment is remarkably well done, neither destroying the flavor nor the mouthfeel of the base beer. A huge beer packed with taste and complexity. For me, this is worth seeking out when it is available.

Tap @ Avery, doing the 10th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Festival. Pours hazy dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma is rich sweet malty with bourbon, caramel, dark chocolate, raisins, oak, vanilla. Taste is roasted rich malts, bourbon, sweet dark fruit, figs, plums, oak, vanilla, brosn sugar. Medium to full body, soft carbonation. Wow what a beer. 090312

My favorite barley wine to date.  Pours a rich, reddish brown. Aroma is beautiful, bourbon, dark chocolate, sweet maltiness, heaven... Flavor is healthy bourbon, which is beautiful, sweet, rich malts, dark chocolate, raisins, dark currants, perhaps, and more dark chocolate. Really rich and super drinkable.

Is good beer.  Bottle is contemporary stucco and roof-slate form with long gooseneck.  Double-ridged topper, for my pleasure.  Corked tight with muffin-top billow.  Soft, sensual cork releases with firm hand, muted explosion ensues.  Bottle-topper contains decorative motif; wonderful for those who collect such things.  And the beer is good.  Try this one.  Skip this review if you want to know about AATP.  Should have written that up front,

Brouwers, Hardliver.

Pours dark with a bit of khaki head. Smell is sweet vanilla and caramel. Taste is heavy, sweet but balanced, almost roasty finish. All the flavors of the brandy version, but not as sharp, a bit more drinkable.

On draft @ TJs 8, 12 oz poured into a chalice. Murky blackish/brown oil slick accompanied by a few small bubbles. Nose is dominated by a blend of bourbon and toffee, along with char and burnt sugar. A nice punch of alcohol hits the palate upfront that eventually warms into sweet bourbon and more overcooked sweets. I have had great Bourbon Angels Share in the past,but this particular keg needed more carbonation and less jet fuel.

2009 Version Reviewed 2010 - The smell of this beer is just simply amazing.  Its a assault on your nose.  Huge amounts of bourbon, caramel, toffee, dark fruits, vanilla, and oak.  I really cant describe this smell.  I mean I just did but its something that needs to be experienced first hand.  Simply awesome.

The taste is world class too but a little bit muted compared to the aroma.  Maybe its the little bit of age I put on the brew.  I dont know but that doesnt mean it isnt a fantastic taste.  The bourbon flavor is king here.  It lingers in your mouth.  Every other flavor is balanced perfectly between the caramel, toffee, dark fruits ,etc.  Alcohol burn plays a big factor in the mouthfeel on this beer.  It burns the mouth, throat, and stomach.   Need a great beer on a cold night, here it is.  It will keep you warm.  The mouthfeel is also thick, syrupy, and coats the mouth.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 This bottle was sent to me as a replacement for an infected, flat bottle of Brandy Angels share that I purchased. Poured into a snifter.

A: Very minimal carbonation evident. Virtually no head whatsoever. It is not completely flat (like the infected bottle of Brandy Angels Share that I had to drainpour) but it is obviously lacking in significant carbonation. Some carbonation does appear upon swirling the glass. Otherwise, pours a dark brown with tinges of dark ruby red evident as well.

S: Bourbon, vanilla, malt, booze, dark fruits. The aroma is enticing. I have smelled better but I have also smelled worse. I think the aroma would be significantly improved if the carbonation were present to a higher degree.

T: I have to say, I do love the taste of this. Very smooth. Lots of vanilla and bourbon for sure. Also get some booze, raisins, figs, dates, brown sugar, and molasses too. Pretty strong malt backbone. A little bit of wood. Hints of chocolate as well. I really cant knock the taste of this one despite the lack of appropriate carbonation. All of the tastes are pretty well balanced in my opinion and I enjoyed it.

M: Again, very little carbonation evident. That being said, this remains a relatively easy drinker in my opinion. A little on the slick side. While some alcohol is evident, it is definitely not overpowering, offensive, or "hot" in the least. I just wish there were more carbonation there.

2011 bottle pours near black with almost no carbonation or head. A small whitish ring clings to the glass, but is nearly non-existent. Served around 55 degrees. Aromas are honeymoon vanilla, raisin and booze. Tastes are sweets caramel, raisin, bourbon, vanilla and toffee. A very complex ale that is for the boubon lover.  Mouthfeel is not that heavy, more medium than I expected. Overall, an amazing beer if you like bourbon. Recommended!

32oz Growler, 2011 Bourbon.  Served at around 45-50F to room temperature.

Pours murky dark brown, nearly black in the glass with a faint brown head that recedes to almost nothing pretty quick.  Second pour was closer to room temp and produced a decent head with slightly better retention.  

Aroma is strong bourbon and a lot of rich, complex malt.  Tons of dark fruit, prunes, figs, raisins, dates, black currants, some molasses, nuts, dark bread/toast, vanilla and oak.  Very good strength.

Flavor starts with a blast of bourbon, oak, vanilla, rich dark fruit and malt, prunes, figs, raisins, black currant, molasses, anise, hints of caramel and bread, dark tobaccos, strong warming alcohol on the finish.  

Mouthfeel is medium-plus bodied, low carbonation, sticky.

Fantastic stuff.  Huge and incredibly complex beer.  You better love bourbon as it isnt subtle at all.  I think I like this a touch better than the Brandy Barrel version.  While I can live with the near lack of carbonation, some bubbles certainly would ramp this up a bit in the appearance and mouthfeel categories.  Letting this warm up to near room temperature really helped open this up a lot.

thanks Kyle! purchased in europe .. . small pop of the cork, light light fizz .. . not infected, which makes this a treat .. . pours a deep ruby molasses .. light foam .. . light bourbon, barrel, touch of vanilla, roast oak, and burnt caramel .. . pretty damn tasty! .. . . Does anybody but me think the hats a little precious?

Bottle, thanks Jeff! Opaque dark brown pour, no head. Lots of bourbon in the aroma, rich vanilla, fresh cream, hazelnuts, tons of oak, rich malty nose and some alcohol. Taste is rich and bourbony, lots of vanilla. Nice malty flavor, rich caramel, toffee. Palate is almost flat, very light carbonation with a big heavy body, very spirit like. I really enjoyed this, despite the flatness, its a good winter warmer for sure.

2008 bottle. Pours a muddy brown but still has a nice bit of carbonation after 3 years. Aroma is - surprise - bourbon!  Actually, this beer is bursting with bourbon.  Some banana and butterscotch flavors run under the bourbon. Its a mouthful and definitely a sipper. The aging has really improved (imho) the quality of this beer. If you like bourbon barrel aged beers and have a 2008 bottle in your cellar - crack it open!

Def worth trying, but the regular angels share is sufficient. I didnt find any real noticeable difference in the bourbon barrel addition. Not enough carbonation, so it was a little too liquorish for me.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Bottle shared at Dajes Place. For the record it was the 2011 edition
Pours murky dark brown with some bubbly head that disappears before my eyes blink. Some laces. Smells of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, toffee. This sure smells like bourbon barreled. Full malt body, good sweetness, some liquor from the barreling i guess.. Quite oily feel, bitter finish. Its a descent beer for sure, but quite heavy. I shared this bottle, and im glad i did. Would really have some difficulties drinking this on my own.
Pours very dark brown. Aroma is bourbon, malty, vanilla and oak. Flavor is bourbon, oak, alcohol, vanilla and caramel malts. Medium to full bodied with a nice sticky finish.

09-DEC-2011, 2010 bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Opens with just a hint of a "puf"-sound.
Pours dark, dark brown - only slightly cloudy - with no head at all.
Nose is wonderfull. Mostly bourbon. Vanilla and dark fruit with molasses.
Taste much the same with a caramelly sweetness and a late alcoholic burn. I can feel and taste the alcohol. But this goes down fine in small amounts at a time. 
No carbonation and off course it would have raised the rating with some carbonation and a small head.
Could drink a lot of this. Really lovely.

2008 375ml Bottle. Dark brown with a small medium beige head. Sweet malt aroma, with lots of bourbon,oak, ripe fruit. The bottel was perfectly carbonated. Sweet matl taste, raisings, vanilla, oak,bourbon,sugar,alcohol and caramel. Slightly vinous touch. Very nice.

Bottle (rated sometime in 2009).

Head is fully diminishing.
Body is murky dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (molasses, chocolate, caramel), with notes of vanilla, honey, bourbon, sherry, alcohol.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Smell is of the richest darkest caramel,  vanilla, concentrated dates and an unwavering deep sweet distilled alcohol.  The flavor is upfront with big saturated toffee and brown sugar, but the overwhelming, dominating force here is that wheat bourbon.  The finish on this stays for quite a bit in the nasal passage and throat.  Whoa, can this one catch you slipping and hurt you if youre not ready.  The mouthfeel is almost exactly that of a port but without the heft on the finish.I so wish that had another because I think in two years this might be the best barleywine that Ive ever tasted.  For now however, its still pretty darn special.  Thank You Lost Abbey.  2011 12.7 oz. bottle.

On tap at Beer Revolution.  Pours a very dark amber with a small tan head that disappears quite quickly and leaves no lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big bourbon, some leather, caramel, a bit of oak, vanilla, and a moderate amount of alcohol.  The initial taste is sweet with caramel and vanilla.  Then comes some bourbon and a light cherry flavor.  The finish is warming and leaves a lingering oak presence.  Surprisingly, the taste is not all that boozy.  Medium-full body.  Low carbonation.  This is quite a tasty beer.  Its sweet, but not cloying.  Im not going to regularly pay the huge price for bottles, but it is certainly worth the price when it is found on tap.

Draft at blue palms LA.  Thick blk with mininmal head.  Ive sworn of Angeles share as the 2010 brandy bottle wa a hot syrupy zero carbonation mess.  This version is a medium body with perfect carbonation.  Sweet caramel a, vanilla and bourbon but the 12% is well hidden.  Excellent.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Tasted November 17. 2011: thick, black and no head. Bourbon in the aftertaste. Shared with the angels. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Lost abbey bou a s.... pitch black, no head, viscous... big oaky bourbony aroma, roasty, some fruits, mild chocolate... lively, full bodied, dryer than expected finish w a light oiliness... huge bourbon flavor oak vanilla dominate, dark fruits subtly underneath, bourbon really dominates.... 8 4 8 5 18

(2010 bottle) Dark brown/cider color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, oak, strong vanilla, bourbon, & dark fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, rich caramel, molasses, vanilla, dark fruit, and some chocolate; Warm booze finish with some smoke; Low carbonation; Very nicely balanced & complex; Wow - this is good stuff.

Yes this was third course 09 BGBBD @ sierra, just sick to know that it was the bourbon instead of the brandy. So dark and happy, Ive had the bourbon in bottle before and loved it and this was no exception. Poured dark with little head. Aromas were huge so much vanilla like I remembered it and thank god I got a snifter of this at the end. Went down too smooth and easy. I could care less about carb issues, this was almost complete and for me was up there with BBVD, BA Boris and Noreaster Cl for best bourbon brews.

Shared bottle at local tasting. Pours dark brown with a small creamy tanned head. Aroma is complex, initially strong alcohol/bourbon but gets better as the beer warms up, dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla and wood. Taste is nice sticky caramel, vinous and mellow velvet. Quite simple, this is delicious.

Draft at Global Brew.  This pours almost completely black and it has a small tan head.  The aroma is wondetful.  Bourbon, vanills, wood, and a bit of chocolate.  Thevflabor matches the nose  but with more bourbon.  Allmof the above comes out distinctly and each part compliments so well.  This doesnt pretend to be complex.  It is straight forward, in your face delicious.  But with a bite.  The ABV is not under stated.  What a good beer.

375 mL bottle. I believe it was from the first bottled release of this beer. The one that was supposed to be uber-carbonated and explosive. Anyway, we chilled it down a lot. The cork was certainly happy to escape, but there was no foam over. The aroma is flat molasses-y, with a bit of cognac on the deeper breathes. The flavor is pretty awesome. Delicious, complex, malty, figgy barleywine. Definitely the bourbon barrel aged one of the too. Nice palate. Not really overcarbed.

Bottle pours dark brown with a thin but legitimate off-white head.  Happy to see a little carbonation in this.  Wonderful aroma of dark fruits, chocolate, coffee, bourbon and raisins.  Taste not qutei as nice as aroma but still good with dark fruits, malt, oak, chocolate and bourbon.  finish with alcohol burn followed by dark fruits and chocolate. Palate and lightly carbonated.
Probably would have benefited from some aging but still just a wonderful beer.

0.375l corked bottle. Im always a bit reluctant to opening these fantastic looking and, for me, quite rare Lost Abbey bottles, but I guess I cant hang on to them forever. This one pours a nice dark dark brown, near-black body with only a really really thin sidesticking tanned line. As good as no head on this one. Aroma is just amazing. Lots of sweet and sticky oaky aromas, theres bourbon, dark caramel, chocolate, lots of sweet rum-raisins, figs and hints of grass and ripe blackberries. Damn! Thats how a oak barrel aged beer is supposed to smell! Soft carbonation, it has a sweet and sticky mouthfeel and quite warming and full-bodied. It most definitely has some fantastic flavors. Its quite sweet, lots of oak, some vanilla, dates and rum-raisins, dark slightly burned caramel and it ends beautifully warming with lots of salty licorice and it has a long lasting heart warming aftertaste. One helluva sipper and just damned good! Lucky angels!

On tap at Twisted Spoke Chicago. Pours very deep amber brown with a small off white froth. Aroma is sweet and very bourbony, woody with some dark fruit, vanilla and cocoa. Flavor is similar, tons of woody bourbon and vanilla, more cocoa than expected with a bite in the finish, a touch boozy. Medium full to full body and a soft carbonation. Interesting beer, a touch too heavy on the bourbon so it pulls away from the balance and complexity, but not bad.

Sample @ SBWF
Quite complex with lots of flavor. Not what I would call a normal beer being flat and drinks more like a fine spirit. Huge notes of vanilla, cinammon, dried fruits, chocolate fudge and syrup. Might re-rate this when I get the chance to try sit with it and concentrate.

75 cl bottle @ Pikkulintu.
Rated on 20110729.
Deep dark red colour with no head. Aroma has some wine-like elements, berries and vanilla. Flavour of stuffy berries, vanilla, caramel and slightly sour and dry redcurrant. Palate is dry and tangy. Very nice.
4335

Thanks DTNot much head blackest of pours mild carbonation wow the bourbon is loaded in aromatic wise with vanilla dark fruits liccorice caramel oak so good flavours the bourbon convincingly strong so full on caramel sweetness the vanilla smoothness comes in nicely rich dark fruits plum raisin well balanced barleywine medium bitter that is superb for the ale the finish bourbon delight vanilla malt goodness hop dark tastes evenly tasting a lasting bitter powerful barleywine taste wise

A deep dark brown barley wine with a thin mocha head. In aroma, superb dark fruits, molasses, floral hops, licorice, vanilla, and bourbon liquor. In mouth, a liquor like ale with nice and warming sweet nutty malt with vanilla, herbal hops, coffee liquor, so beautiful and balanced. Wow! On tap at Sunset Grill, Oct. 8 2011.

2010 Bottle poured into a few taster glasses. I had intended to open this one and then the 2009 but we struggled to finish this one.
A - Pours deep dark brown, mostly black, with a thin film of off-white head leaving no lace at all down the glass.
S - Smells of chocolate, vanilla, toffee, toasted wood, and warming bourbon. The booze is still VERY strong in this one but the base flavors are very nice.
T - Starts off with a nice mix of chocolate, vanilla, and toffee sweetness quickly giving way to a STRONG alcohol burn, lingering through the finish and then some. The bourbon is ever present, offering a warming sensation that blends well with the base flavors. I think a bit more time in the bottle would have done this one wonders but I didnt want to wait and find out it was flat. Oh well.
M - Heavy body and flavor with low carbonation. Big, heavy, feel with a mix of dark flavors and strong alcohol burn in the finish.
O - I have had this on-tap and it was much better than this. The flavors are complex and very enjoyable but it is just WAY too hot. Once it tones down a bit this will be a great beer but at the moment it is still too raw.

Bottle. 2008 edition. As my no. 4400 rating. Pours hazy deep amber with a small creamy off white head. The aroma has strong notes of bourbon, wood, oak, loads of raisins, dates, sweet caramel, vanilla a good kick of warming alcohol. The flavour is at first extremely fruity with a long sourish kick in the finish. Then notes of bourbon, wood, raisins, grapes and sour berries, light tobacco and then the warming alcohol. Simply fantastic!

Bottle, shared by Plovmands #4400 .....pours black with light tan head.... the aroma is sooo nice ... bourbon, dark fruits, dates, wood, vanillia... the flavor is bitter sweet very soft in the begining but gets sour after, very nice special taste....many flavors....bourbon, port, dark fruits, grapes, wood.... very nice ! ..... special...
Pours opaque dark brown with a wonderful aroma of oak, heat, sweet malt, and caramel. The beer drinks like it smells. Although its very well balanced in terms of the heat.

The smell is caramely, sweet, hot, slight woody and an obvious bourbon present aroma. The appearance is very dark, pretty much no head of course, and swirling it in your glass just makes you feel like you are seeing pure beauty. The taste is so smooth. This beer is very drinkable.

On tap at Livewire. Blackish beer with a huge tan head. Bourbon aroma with malt and a bit of chocolate. Bourbon flavor with malt, chocolate, vanilla, and oak. Fuller bodied. LIngering bourbon. Needs a bit of time. I like the regular version better as the bourbon starts to compete a bnit here without fully complementing. Still a great beer though.

375 mL bottle bought at Binnys in downtown Chicago. caged and [tightly] corked, pouring out a liquid chocolate color with minimal head and minimal carbonation. heavy bourbon aroma, full of oak and vanilla and alcohol with rich malt and barely perceptible green hops - a nice blend of whiskey and beer, ending up velvety smooth thanks to a fair amount of residual sugar. toast, more booze and sweet malt apparent behind the evaporative bourbon. very full bodied, and it finishes with an unsurprising sweet heat. very nice, a port-like digestif which would pair nicely with a rare steak or a creme brulee.

Toasted coconut, bourbony aroma.  Deep brown in color with off-white head.  Deep, toasty, a bit of chocolate with toasted coconut and caramel notes.

Notes:  On tap at GABF 11

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2015 Retate, Linköping Beer Expo 2015. Wonderful. Just wonderful! 
Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival 2011. Dark amber beer with a small head. Malty whiskey aroma, woody, vanilla and some milk. Whiskey flavor, oak, wood, vanilla, milky, hoppy notes, figs, raisins.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 Sampled @ SBWF on September 29. Pours a deep amber with almost no head. Smell is sweet with vanilla and a distinct alcohol character. It very much smells like bourbon. Taste is very sweet with vanilla and that distinct warm bourbon taste that comes with the smell.Re-rate! Ive learned to like stuff like this a lot more since my initial rating. Has aged with dignity. Really damn good!
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Black with a small brown head. Smells alcohole chocolates and smoky. Smells chocolate, malty and abit alcohole with a similar finish.

Sample @ SBWF 2011. Pours deep mahogany no head. Aroma is sweet barrel sweet vanilla raisins madeira, fantastic. Flavor is fullbodied vinous oak sweet vanilla bourbon malty bitter. Finishes sweet fruity.

Very unimpressed. When bourbon barrel aging is done well, it can make a beer absolutely world class. This is not an example of that. It didnt add any complexity, you didnt notice much wood, and it didnt improve upon the regular release in any serious way. You just got bourbon, bourbon, and sweet. Thats the only notes I got. Bourbon, sweet, and alcohol. All the way through. Really disappointed. Been wanting to try this for a while, and dont think Ill be going back for seconds.

Bottle. Pours an opague dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma is filled with bourbon, wood, oak, caramel, dried dark fruits like figs, prunes and raisins, vanilla, toffee and molasses. The flavor is very dark fruity with alot of figs burnes and bourbon soaked raisins, I also get lots of bourbon, oak and some vanilla along with caramel, toffee, molasses a light toasted note and some faint alcohol notes, with an alcohol burn. The body is full with a sticky mouthfeel, but unfortunately this beer doesnt have much of carbonation more of gentile effervesence. Overall a really nice and hughe Barley Wine!
Pours a dark, dark brown.  Aroma is really strong and a little sweet.  That bourbon really shines through.  Not super viscous but slides down the throat easy.  I also get a touch of vanilla.

Pours dark toffee color. Small head that is quick to disappear and leaves no lacing. Perhaps there was only a head because I forced the pour. Smells like bourbon. Tastes like bourbon. Way too  much like bourbon. The base beer was perhaps better before the brandy infiltrated. Actually the base beer was better. This was just middle of the road and seems like another gimmick in the wood/limited/crazy release game.

From 375ml bottle at the brewery w Andy, James and Dallas. Deep black pour with negligible head... Nose is sweet bourbony wood with a surprising smoothness. Taste is sweet, light alcohol with a smooth mouthfeel that is probably unmatched by anything Ive ever drinken. Given the abv, I cant believe how silky and tasty this is. Could drink all night.

Murky brown, hardly any carbonation, just a film of a head.
Strong bourbon aroma, and there is a pleasant whiskey edge to the proceedings. 
Strong sweet malt kept under control by hops and barrels. Oak, strong alcohol warming.

2009 bottle...pours an opaque brown with ruby hues...very thin mocha head.  Aroma has notable bourbon, vanilla, red licorice, dark fruit, and a bit of boozyness.  Flavor has loads of bourbon and oak...also vanilla, fig, and raisin...bit of earthy hops.  Mouthfeel is a little silky with a very warming earthy bourbon finish.  Great use of bourbon barrels!

2010 Vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: I heard a pop when uncorking the bottle, yay looks like it is carbonated, pours a dark brown/black colour with a mahogany/burgundy hue with no real head to speak of,  smell is lots & lots of prunes, smells like half dried prunes or prune jam with a decent portion of sirop de Liège mixed in there as well, also plenty of bourbon with spices & some brown sugar, taste is once again lots of prunes, molasses, thick syrup, brown sugar, dark fruits, figs, caramel, toffee, maple syrup, sirop de Liège, maybe some malt, raisins, liquor, if there is wood to be found in here, it is buried underneath, somewhere there, it is flat, sweet & very syrupy followed by lots of bourbon (also syrupy bourbon) & booze, it is warming but the alcohol is very noticeable in this & very wine like, the alcohol does hit you, serious stuff, is it worth it? Probably, it is a bit hard to say but interesting it definitely is, an attack on the senses all right

375ml from Santa. Pours murky dark brown with very small tan head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, rich caramel, and brown sugar. Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, sweet caramel malts, dark fruits, and brown sugar. A bit flat mouthfeel, but still a very nice beer regardless.

Bottle, sample.
Dark reddish brown, no head.
Aroma: chocolate, licorice, toffee, an acidity.
Taste: acidic, alcohol, licorice, chocolate, toffee, caramel, dry finish.
Full-bodied, flat.
Another Angels Share Im disappointed by. Its good, but had expected something extra.
black pour. very little carbonation.  Very strong caramel and vanilla hints.  Oaky tastes comes just slights after.  Seems to taste better as it warms.  One of my favorites!

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 Tasted on 8/26/11 from a corked and caged 375mL bottle, this is the 2010 vintage with the black label.  Pours an opaque, extremely dark brown with a thin, bubbly tan head that recedes pretty quickly to nothing more than a thin collar of lace.  The nose is really great, with molasses, maple, brown sugar, bourbon, toasted coconut, caramel, toffee, cinnamon, vanilla oak, and just a bit of earthy yeast.  The flavor is more of the same, with a complex blend of caramel, brown sugar, toffee, maple, molasses, fig, date, bourbon, cinnamon, charred vanilla oak, chocolate, toasted coconut, bourbon, lightly earthy yeast, and just a touch of alcoholic heat.  The body is full and syrupy with light carbonation and a super long charred vanilla oak, coconut, lightly bitter, and tannic finish.

If by some freak chance you get anything from LA that is not flat it is going to be world class. Unfortunately your more likely to drop $20 on a 375 and have a flat average brew that will really piss you off because even as a flat mess you will be able to see how amazing it would be if LA could solve their carbonation issues. Of you see it on tap jump on it. If you see it bottled and like to be cock teased, lay down the cash

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The Flemish proverb goes: "Its like an angel peeing on my tongue." I subscribe to that.

Just not getting into this, it is flat first off, and that makes it drink like syrup is in my glass. sticky and while the flavors are alright, it is hard to really get into this muck to pick much other then caramel and booze out. Pass.

375ml bottle from the IPB. 2010 written below the label.

Appearance : Opens with no sound. Black with no head. Little bubbles.

Aroma : Rich bourbon notes with figs and raisins. Overcooked caramel notes. Some vanilla with notes of alcohol. Great chewy malts behind the alcohol.

Taste : Rather well balanced. Fruity figs and raisins with light bourbon notes. Finish gets more intense with strong bourbon presence (but not that much vanilla notes). Rather bitter combined with the alcohol bite makes it rather sharp. Nice caramel and fruity sweetness. Nice lingering warmth.

Palate : Very light fizz on the tongue. Carbonation seemed almost absent at first but its actually there but very subtle. Almost absent at first but it tickled the tongue on the finish.

Overall : Very complex with a very nice bourbon presence. Still quite warm and a bit too alcoholic for my taste but it goes well with the beer. Awesome winter sipper. Nevertheless, Im slightly disappointed by this. I would have liked a little bit more carbonation and a bit less alcohol. Still, its very complex and very well balanced except for the alcohol. I feel the complexity and finesse behind all the alcohol but have a hard time getting the most of it. It seems others had more carbonated bottles. Ill re-rate if I ever get a chance.

Funky shaped 2009 375 ml bottle. Pours a cloudy brown color with a modest tan head. Aroma is malty, dark fruit, bourbon and wood. Flavor had some caramel, vanilla, burnt sugar, and bourbon warmth. Finish is sweet with loads of vanilla and woodiness. Smooth drinker.  Nice stuff.

Bottle thanks to ketchepillar. We are pretty sure what we have here is a 2007 bottle of this here Angels Share Bourbon Barrel. Whatever vintage it is, it was the one that was supposed to be over carbonated. After some time in the freezer the cork still shot out of this one with ease. The beer pours a deep reddish brown color with a small well retained head and some good lace. The aroma is stinky feet for quite a while till the beer warms and plenty of cordial and bourbon show up. Its a pretty pungent smelling beer throughout though. The flavor has lots of sweet vanilla driver bourbon character and loads of malty and roasty flavors. Plenty of cordial liqueur shows up here. The beer is very viscous and the carbonation at a higher level doesnt seem to be much of a problem. I always suspected Id like this one if I got a good bottle, and we sure got a good bottle. 
This bottle seems to have a pretty minimal "aged" quality to it despite its years at rest.

2008 Vintage 375ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours pitch black with minimal head. Aroma has notes of vanilla, oak, malts and slightly dark berries and caramel. Taste is slightly red winish and sour with notes of vanilla, oak, malts and berries. A bit sticky and smooth finish. Nice, quite wine like barrel aged beer.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2013 375 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, Helsinki. 2008 version.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small faint head on the edges. Aroma of sweet bourbon, oak and strong vanilla. Flavour of lovely vanilla and oak barrel, sour fruits, some hops and chocolate. Quite smooth mouthfeel with a finish of oak, vanilla and some roastiness. Alcohol warms nicely. Nice barley wine with sourness, hits my sweet spot.

37,5 cl bottle vintage 2008 @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, no BBE info
Aroma is rather stale. It has lots of vanilla and sweet malt and raisins with alcohol. Sourish flavour has very stinging alcohol, vanilla, raisins and sweet malt. Lots wood and harsh bitterness. Reminds me of red wine. Not really my kind of beer, too intense and harsh.

14/07/2011 12.7 Fl. Oz. bottle @ Klaas place (2011-328) Thanks to Klaas for the bottle!
Dark brown beer, little cloudy, residue floating around. No head. Aroma: port, orange peel, alcohol, dried fruits, caramel. MF: light but ok carbon, full body. Taste: chocolate explosion! Some red berries first, then chocolate, port, wood, mocha, dark chocolate towards the end. Aftertaste: red berries, chocolate, more port notes, nuts, vanilla touch.

2010 bottle that poured a dark black with no head whatsoever, really no carbonation at all with this pour.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, and molasses.  Flavors match the aroma with a caramel note at the end.

2010 vintage. 37.5 cL bottle at the brewery, served in a branded stem. Pours dark chestnut with virtually no head. On the nose, there are big notes of bourbon, oak and vanilla, along with liquorice, molasses, caramel and earth. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with lots of whiskey, toasty malts and subtle earthy, herbal hops for balance. The finish is long with whiskey and alcohol notes, along with a touch of molasses. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and almost no carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent barley wine with a strong bourbon character. The brandy is quite intense, perhaps a little too dominant. 2011-06-06

old notes, lucky enough to try this sucker at SAVOR...currently the top rated non-retired barleywine.  

Looks like whisky coming out of the bottle almost...pours borwn with minimal carbonation...Perhaps looks like iced tea most of all.  Bourbon is dominant throughout.  Lots of caramel as well.  Finish is long and lingering with a slight alcohol burn.  Its good, but when I want whisky I just go get a bottle and drink that, when I want beer, its not with the goal of drinking whisky.

[3746-20110526] 12.7floz bottle. Wooden barrel and heavy burnt Brazil nut and Tootsie Roll malt aroma. Murky, black brown body with no lasting head. Lots of barrel wood malt with roasted fruity fig and a hint of nuttiness in the flavour. Medium-full body. Tasty and enjoyable. (8-/3-/8/3/16) 3.8
Bottle @ Stone World Bistro. Pours rich dark brown with little to no head. Aroma of rich dried fruits with a bourbon, chocolate backbone. Bourbon very much in the foreground with warm alcohol notes.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Finally able to get a bottle of this since I had only tasted the brandy barrell on several occasions.  Poured into my pint glass as a thick and creamy liquid with a deep and dark shade of mahogany hue and was topped by a small layer of foam as a head. The aroma was incredibly bold of whiskey bourbon barrel, raisin, wood, maple syrup, cigar tobacco, caramel and dried fig or date. Basically, the scent of this beer is all over the place and that earns a perfect score because of quickly it made me salivate.  After taking my first few sips, I could tell this was a much more rounded version of Angels Share and it seemed the wood from the bourbon was much more apparent.  There is a sweet base of sugary syrup like malts that dominate over all else, but there is also room for a strong dosage of alcohol that reminds me of vodka or a bland flavored whiskey. Also, a touch of raisin or fig is noticed in the aftertaste and a sweet residue of a high quality cigar.  Top notch stuff, and I could only imagine how refined this would taste from a cask or tap.

Bottle shared at beer temple.  Dark brown pour with almost no head. Aroma of BA vanilla/bourbon, with roast malts, chocolate.  Flavor very sweet with bourbon, vanilla and thick caramel.  Alcohol warmth in aftertaste.
Hugely complex barley wine.  The bourbon really comes through on the nose and taste to compliment the dark fruits and medium sweetness.  A great offering from lost abbey.

2011-05-26. Very dark brown-black body, small tan head fades quickly. 3+ First aroma notes are of a woody malt melange that is a bit reminiscent of Thomas Hardys. The character has blended together in a way that makes it tough to separate it out, bourbon, but it presents differently from most bourbon beer. Flavour is similar, a malty base with interesting bourbon character weaved throughout, hints of what could uncharitably be described as marmite are more generously attributed to a wood-bourbon-malt melange that I find alternately intriguing and off-putting. Dry bourbon notes in the finish with a mild bitterness from the alcohol. Alcohol presence is surprisingly restrained for the strength, but makes itself known by warming the throat and stomach. Malt fades out a bit as it warms, with the bourbon coming more to the forefront, but overall it is surprisingly smooth and the bourbon is more pleasant to my tastes than many others. Smooth medium to full bodied palate is nearly uncarbonated.Ultimately it is not to my tastes enough that I would drink it regularly, but I find it very interesting. I enjoyed the second half of the glass more than the first, after I acclimated to the bourbon character.   Does not have the depth of rich malt sweetness that I remember from the brandy version. Pretty solid but I had high expectations. Bottle purchased 7/2010 from Bottleworks, Seattle

375 ml brown cork and cage bottle. Dark brown almost black. Vigourous pour yielded very little head if any. The aroma is strong with vanilla/bourbon barrel character. Lots of caramel, toasted malt, dark fruits, wood, and maple syrup. Wow that is a big aroma. The taste has vanilla/bourbon barrel character, smack with caramel and a lot  heat from the alcohol. Even being 12.5% ABV I am still surprised at how hot it is. My wife thought it tasted like liquor. Maybe she wanted me to liquor.

375ml bottle from 2010. Pours a hazy dark brown with a reddish tinge, no head but carbonation. Amazing snoof - sweet, plums, vanilla, bourbon, nice and full bodied, initially sweet, get some alcohol with vanilla and wood, a little thin on the finish compared to on tap but still delicious. Bottles are getting better with age but think they still need some more time to let the alcohol mellow.
On tap at champs. aroma is bourbon and vanilla. Flavor is bourbon, vanilla, caramel and oak. Very nice.
bourbon & caramel aroma and taste with a coffee and resin palate, good balance of yeast, malt and hops... This is a incredible malt beverage, the name says it all
Dark cloudy brown with no head at all. No presence of carbonations. Aroma is wood, alcohol, caramel, chocolate. Medium body. Flavours are caramel, bitter, herbs.

2009 and 2010 vintages tried side-by-side, 375 ml bottles each. The 2009 is from JCB and the 2010 from another generous trader on here- just cant remember who. Pours a deep, dark brown with a tiny beige ring for a head. Big bourbon nose on each of these, with a little more balance emerging from the 2010 version, complemented by notes of oak, tannins, caramel, dark fruits, and toasted brown sugar. The flavor brings some bourbon heat, curiously more from the 2009, along with vanilla, caramel, molasses, dark fruits, and brown sugar. Medium-full bodied, with low carbonation and a smooth, boozy mouthfeel. Really nice bourbon barrel barleywine, and I think I prefer the 2010 to the 2009.

Bottle at CL Rosso Batch 3 Release. Pours hazy brown with basically no carbonation. Very strong aroma with lots of dark fruit, caramel, booze, dates, vanilla. Very strong alcohol bite, very flavorful, more dark fruit and sweet caramel. Quite tasty, looking forward to trying this again, preferably after 7am this time.

375ml bottle (bourbon Barrel release), release date 04/03/2010.  Purchased at Holiday Liquors, Escondido, CA.  Pours dark brown/ black with a small tan head.  Minimal carbonation.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, caramel, malt and alcohol.  Taste is bourbon, vanilla, sweet and boozy, but make no mistake, bourbon is the "spirit" (no pun intended) of this complex ale.  The finish is set up as alcohol warms the mouth, giving way to a smooth bourbon after taste.  This reviewer much prefers the bourbon barrel release to the more common and easily obtained brandy barrel Angels Share.  This is more than ale, this is brewing art!!!

Aroma: mixt of  bourbon and fudge, caramel...
Apparence.. dark brown,, tiny tan head... 
Flavor: alcohol , caramel, bourbon....

Corked bottle, vintage 2009, 1½ years oldThe color is dark brown, almost black; flat. The aroma mainly comes from the vanilla oak, with notes of chocolate and Sherry. The body is strong, the mouthfeel can be at times oily; strong chocolate flavor, quite sweet, but counterbalanced by liquorice and alcohol; also a good vanilla presence; the high alcohol content creates a nice warming feeling in the end. Very good.

(bottle - corked & caged 375 ml) Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Heavy bourbon and oak aroma with a nice and big malt backbone. Flavor is tons of malt, dark fruits, caramel, vanilla, oak and bourbon. The alcohol is very warming and the bourbon is extremely potent. Sweet and boozy on the finish with a smooth aftertaste.
Had on tap at Sunset Grille in MA.  Very good beer.  Malty and a good amount of heat from the bourbon.  Highly recommended.

Had this side by side with the brandy barrel aged and I preferred the brandy slightly to this one.

Poured from a bottle into a standard pint glass. Lots of head, beer smells slightly sweet but really strong liquor. Beer is brown, dark brown. There isnt much to say about it really. It was sweet, strong, mostly liquor tasting but surprisingly drinkable. Whatever the base of this bal aged beer is it was overwhelmed by the aging process. Im curious if it was aged in "wet" barrels.

Serving type: bottle

Not my style of choice, however; this beer bring a lot of complexity to the table. The bourbon is really the main focus here with some other notes of dried fruits and chocolate coming through. High alcohol obviously leads to some low carbonation, but it seemed even lower than a normal 12.5% beer. I aged this beer since i purchased it in my cellar.

The beer pours a very dark brown, you can really tell the difference between brown and black on this one. There is no carbonation at all. No head comees up at all. 

The aroma is super sweet and matly. Vanilla dominates this then you get some nice notes of brandy, and wood.

The taste is all malt, tons of vanilla again almost all the way through the finish. At the end there is a little wood and an alcoholic finish.

The feel is really weak here. Its very light feeling without much of a finish. There is a light warm feel.

Overall, this is ok, nothing special, the grand cru crushes this.
A bourbon flavor explosion. Poors a very dark brown/burgandy. Lots of malt, vanilla, oak. No head and very little to no bubbly. This is deffinetly one of the best.

On tap at Sunset. Black pour. Aroma is oak, raisin, alcohol, dark fruit chocolate. Flavor is raisin, alcohol, bourbon, oak. Very sweet. Dried fruit, figs. Round mouthfeel with a sharp finish, warming like whiskey. Intense, flavorful. An explosion of flavor in my mouth.

from Erzbierschof.ch - cloudy and very dark brown colour with absolutely no foam left; solid and complex aroma of wood, bourbon, licorice and walnut; low carbonation and gently sticky, solid malt backbone and pretty thick, a solid bitterness and a long tart woody aftertaste with notes of walnuts and vanilla - huge!

12.7 ounce 2010 bottle.  This is another good beer that does not live up to the hype or pricetag.  Pours a murky mahogany with no head.  Great aroma of malt sweetness, bourbon, wood and a little vanilla.  Flavor follows with the aroma.  Sweet, oaky, full of bourbon, some dark dried fruits and alcohol heat.  Little carbonation, and a full body.  I wish that it had more carbonation.  I would like to try it with more age on it.
I really liked this but was a little taken aback by the lack of carbonation...I should learn to leave my expectations at the door when trying things for the first time.

pours dark brown with little to no head.  Nice sweet oakiness on the nose.  Not as boozy on the nose or in the taste vs the brandy.  It has next to no hop character, taste of vanilla, slight chocolate, and dark fruit (plum).  Much prefer this to the brandy barrel.  It is nice and smooth.

On tap at BCP.  Dark brown pour edging toward black, barrel character comes to dominate the original beer.  Vanilla, woodsy oak, medicinal maltiness.  Licorice, chocolate, wine in lesser shades.  Feel is viscous and smooth like velvety Port, just tastes expensive and classy.  Do I rate this as highly in a blind test?  Its certainly a high-Three.

This beer looks like sewer water with its deep, dirty dark brown that is remarkably cloudy. Nice aroma with great bourbon sweetness.  Great coffee and bourbon all over the taste. Velvety full mouthfeel is well-rounded from the bourbon barrel.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2014 12.7 oz corked and caged brown bottle. 2010 vintage. 12.5% alcohol.

It pours a dark brown with a fizzy off-white head that never gets very large and dissipates immediately with no lacing.
