The smell is dominated by bourbon through and through. There are hints of oak, alcohol, and fruits. It isnt super complex, mainly bourbon. There is a hint of chocolate that hints in but never becomes super noticeable.

The bourbon dominates the flavor, though it isnt as alcoholic as I was expecting. It has some caramel, vanilla, and oak, but that is about it. There is some walnuttiness that comes through, almost like a stale maibock in the finish I was hoping for something with more complexity, this is basically bourbon flavored beer.

The bottle was overpriced, it is a bit overhyped.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-17-2010 06:08:07 3/5

had a 08 last night. downgraded further.

Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black. No head. Nice aroma, lots of vanilla notes from the barrel, also some licorice and smokiness. The taste has a lot of bourbon in it. In fact I have never tasted anything that has tasted as much of the barrel as this beer. Also some vanilla/cream. Lots of alcohol (too much). The body is a little too thin to handle all the alcohol and barrel notes.
Bottle (75 cl). Dark reddish brown, tiny brief beige head. Malty, toffeish aroma, with dried fruits, chocolate, and some vanilla barrel notes. Medium to full bodied, flat carbonation. Well balanced.

Bottle.
Pours heavy brown black without any head.

Lots of bourbon taste and aroma, the beer feels a slightly to light for all the booze. Taste of burbon filled chcoholates

Bottle thanks to Honka and Delaval (non ratebeer friends).
Sampled on February 26, 2011
2009 version, though marked 12.5% ABV
Very dark brown to black color, small tan head. Oak, wood, alcohol, sweet scent. SWeet, oak, alcohol, vanilla taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Alcohol and vanilla aftertaste.

2008 bottle courtesy of nbutler 11, thanks very much!  Loud pop, massive brown head with very long retention.  Aroma of burnt caramel syrup, port wine, raisins.  Taste is sweet balsamic vinegar, dates, chocolate syrup.  Tastier than the brandy barrel version.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2011 Bottle (Thx tarheels, gotta love it when your roommate hands you a glass of a top 50 beer without even asking!). Pour is not looking too hot. No carbonation with a deep ruby/mahogony color. Aroma is fantastic - getting prune juice, raisins, bourbon, vanilla, rum, framboise; I could smell this for hours. Taste is good too: very buttery, sweet, rich, with more raisin/rum and a bit of booziness in the finish (though still very nice). Didnt really strike me as a barleywine, actually kind of reminded me of Older Viscosity. Will re-rate when I try again with carbonation.

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from Julios Liquors.  The nose is sweet with notes of port, molasses, and toasted nuts.  The flavor has a ton of vanilla, some oak, lots of dark raisin character and some port notes.  Very impressive as an after dinner drink.  Dark, rich and delicious, but no carbonation which actually suits this brew well.  I have to say, this one lives up to the hype.

375mL 2010 ed. Pours a tepid deep red to mahogany with bubbles but no head formation. Aroma reminds me a bit of Sam Adams Triple Bock but before the gross flavors come to light: heavy tawny port, musty cellar, damp wood, massive rum raisin, malaga gelato, light coffee, light sweet brandy, buttery ganache, even port grapes and dark dessert wine. Intense, soft, and the highlight of the beer. The taste is soft, buttery, raisin heavy, with some powerful, sharp alcohol kick that is not hot whatsoever but definitely present giving this quite the intense bite in the back end. Medium bodied with light grape skin tartness and tannins. A quick, dusty palate verges on cardboardy but is saved but lingering butteriness. Overall its a bit too sweet and cola heavy in the body and thin on the palate that it seems to me like bourbon, cherry coke, and ice cream. Certainly a delicious combination, but not really barleywine. Tannic, dry, near papery palate is not helping much either. I think I liked it better on tap with some carbonation.

Pours no head so no lace. Deep brown almost black color, ton of yeast left in bottle.  No carbonation and medium-heavy bodied.  Nose is bourbon, flavor is slightly sweet bourbon. High ABV is up front. Needs some carbonation, there are 11.5% beers out there that have carbonation like Harpoons Leviathan Triticus. Very warming. This is bottle #3000 for my collection!! Seriously expensive at $18.99 for a caged and corked 375ml bottle from Julios Liquors Westborough, Ma.

Appearance - Dark, opaque maroon-raisin colour that almost turns clearer towards the edge as if a pure alcohol "floater" were present (which there very well could be at 12½%)! No head at all, no; none whatsoever. Gone. (Save for a few "archipelagos" in a very dark sea, and when swirled they slide down the glass VERY sllloooow).

Aroma - Woooow... yummy. Strong sweet whiskey notes for sure, (kinda Yukon Jack-like nose actually) sweet caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, molasses, faint toasted coconut even, definately expressive.

Taste - Follows the nose.Soft Scotch-Bourbon, vanilla, rich caramelly oak faint coconut. Not too sweet but definitely dessert! Boozy notes adding to the dark rum-raisin-surprise complexity for sure, oh;.. its rich baby,.. its rich!

Mouthfeel - Heavy syrupy body, mild carbonation, coatingly luxurious.

Drinkability/Overall - Amazing. Duh definitely NOT a session beer (can you say "too loaded"), but so smooth its ridiculous for what is essentially "wine." A top "nightcap nipper!"
I was really having a tough time coughin up $16 for a 375ml, but really wanted to taste it bad enough, sure glad I did. This beer really highlights bourbon barrel aging in a way I have yet to experience. Allagash Curieux was smooth but I could barely tell, whereas this REALLY lets the whiskey notes sing. Love this ale alright,.. probably too much for how bad it stings the pocketbook!

On draft @ Sunset Grill and Tap, Allston, MA.  Pours deep mahogany brown with no head at all. No or little carbonation. Aroma is dominated by the bourbon casks, big oak, dark fruit, candy sugar. Taste is immense on the bourbon too. Dry oak, lots of sweet dark fruits, candy sugar as well,  and sweet liquorice. A faint amount of alcohol taste as well. Only a tad of bitterness to balance out the sweetness. Mouthfeel is very thick, almost oily texture and flat as a pancake, wow! what a brew!

375 bottle. Pours a still, dark brown. The nose is prunes, raisins, vanilla, oak, and a lot of bourbon. The flavors were dark fruits, caramel, vanilla, oak and bourbon. Like the nose the bourbon comes through a lot and I think too much. I prefer the brandy version to this one. The brandy truly complements the flavors where the bourbon I feel overpowers it. This is still a good beer and I would never turn it down. I would like to try a version thats been aged a bit to see if the bourbon settles a bit.

2009 vintage

A- Body is a translucent, nearly opaque dark brown body. A rather aggressive pour still leaves this beer flat-with absolutely no head. Flat abbey strikes again (actually Ive had probably 20 or so brews from them and this is only the second or third flat one).

S- Nose is potent and pretty much as the bottle describes-A ton of caramel malt and bourbon characteristics, as well as a good amount of alcohol astringency. A mild to moderate amount of wet oak looms in the background as well as the slightest touch of toffee and chocolate.

T-Overall impression of the taste is slightly sweet, slightly boozy. Its got a good bit of caramel and molasses to it and the heat comes in up front. Letting the sip linger on the palate really brings out a lot of complexity with chocolate, oak, and toffee- the finish has a touch of what seems to be an impression of candi sugar before the heat returns-and lingers on and on.

M- Mild carbonation and a thick, viscous body that would be ultra velvety smooth if it wasnt for the alcohol consistency/astringency with a moderate presence. The feel isnt nearly as flat as the appearance.

D- This is an interesting beer overall. Kind of comes off as a BA scotch ale-which is a very cool concept-and I havent tried many. The bourbon is a little hot and heavy and I probably could have been a bit more patient with this one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-10-2011 02:40:40
This is one very complex beer, the bourbon isnt overwhelming and theres are just layers and layers of malt sugar, corn traits, and molasses. Very impressive

Bottle from Beermerchants.com, shared with Slothez at home watching the Superbowl. Deep dark brown pour with a lingering tan head. Nose was predominantly bourbon and chewy sweet malts. Flavour followed suit with the  bourbon, vanilla and barrel notes jigging across the palate with some well placed hoppage lurking in the shadows. Beautifully smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Alcohol exceedingly welll smothered pushing the drinkability factor through the roof. Quality to burn here. Rollicking good beer.    .

Bottle, to celebrate the Arsenal enduring some of the finest counter-attacking football of later years; not being humiliated and coming back for a sensational win!

Had this laying down in my cellar for some while so thought sod it ill have this. Thanks to Beermerchants for the supply.

White lacing which simmers down quickly to leave a death black tar wonder of blackness, maybe the beer of the Apocalypse??? Its as black as they get. 

Aroma is like an unsuspecting uppercut, FULL on candi-sugar, marzepan, barely, black currents, figgs, raisins, chocolate,  oak, leathery goodness and some citrus hidden gently. 

Taste is striking; exhaustingly complicated, the senses lit up devinely. I am knocked out. Thick velvet, rich Belgian truffle chocolate, marzepan, candi-sugar, treacle oozes down my throat like a juggernaut, STUNNING blending, balance is superb. malt is stunning, loads of nice booze and whiskey but the descent stuff, wood, oak, cherries, soy source, leather, could really do with some coffee, damn this is drinking so well and Im flabbergasted and astounded. This is one sensational bw and deserved of a top fifty slot.  Smoke me a kipper; Ill be back for breakfast. Im knocked out. Hats off.

Bottle @ home. Dark red purple appearance with absolutely no head. Initially a whiskey and oak barrel aroma followed by the sweetness, red fruit-like, and wine-like body. Very strong flavor again initially a sweet whiskey and a vanilla tasting oak flavor. After that you get more of the barley wine flavor, lots of sweetness, some fruit flavors, and a wine-like flavor. Vanilla, oak, and booze on the finish. Very tasty and complex brew!

Bottle from Brewdog bar, Aberdeen. Pours a deep brown colour with no trace of head and minimal carbonation. Nose; BOURBON, vanilla, wood, syrup, honey, cinnamon, nutmeg. Taste; bourbon taste and warmth, syrupy mouth-feel, wood, smoky, burnt sugar, plums, cherries, vanilla, walnuts, brazil nuts and a long warming finish. A great winter warmer!

Strong aroma is quite fruity, what I expect from a barleywine, with a syrupy feel and an overtone of caramel and brown sugar. It pours a dark opaque chocolate brown with a thin tan head that quickly hits the road. Flavor is fruity with hints of caramel, brandy and molasses and a strong but not too fierce alcohol bite. Texture is smooth as almond milk with a nice sharp and ragged edge. This one is spendy, but if you are a barleywine nut Im sure it will be up your alley.

375ml bottle, 2010.  Pours a thick, opaque dark brown with absolutely no head and not much apparent carbonation. Aroma is rather complex, with notes of toffee, vanilla, coffee and cocoa beans, with hints of oak and alcohol. Flavor is mostly roasted malts, with some coffee and dried fruits, spicy alcohol notes along with oak and bourbon. Lingering sweet bourbon/boozy finish. Excellent but definitely a special occasion type beer.

Pours a slightly hazy dark brown with faint ruby highlights when held to light. Lots of carbonation produced a huge fluffy off white head that impaled itself to the sides of the glass. Smells of bourbon, licorice, toffee, some higher alcohols and maybe a faint brett type smell. Tastes of sweet malt, some plums, some alcohol, some bourbon. Carbonation is a bit high and affects the mouthfeel a bit feels prickly with carbonation as well as a bit syrupy. Heavy thick body. Good brew, I wish the carbonation was a bit lower, but overall solid brew. At 15 dollars plus shipping for a little more than 12 ounces I can safely say that I probably wont seek this one out again.
Delicious. Very heavy on the bourbon. 2010 vintage. Hot, but delicoius. Sweet molassis and vanilla and maple syrup. Nice

From notes:

2008 vintage. Pours pitch black and completely opaque with only the slightest of mahogany edges when held to a light source. Two finger frothy beige head with decent retention, only slowly fading into a thin lasting ring. Sporadic splotches f lacing left behind. Ah, the good old days when LAs big beers were properly carbonated.

The barrel aging has resulted in a boozy bourbon aroma with hints of earthy oak, vanilla and marshmallow. Underneath the huge bourbon barrel presence theres hints of roasted malt, smoke, chocolate, caramel and toffee. All of these elements are blended nicely, creating a very impressive nose.

Medium bodied and better balanced than the aroma suggests. I was expecting a massive, one dimensional bourbon bomb but this beer is very complex with multiple flavors bouncing off of each other. As in the aroma, the bourbon barrel presence is dominant with hints of sweet booze, earthy oak and sweet vanilla notes. The flavor of the bourbon is strong but this beer isnt very hot and the high ABV is well masked. Underneath the bourbon there is some luscious chocolate malt, toffee, caramel, smoke and coffee bean. Slightly roasted with a very subtle lactic creaminess adding to the complexity and improving drnikability. Nice warmth in the finish.

This was the first vintage of this beer that Ive sampled and it exceeded all of my expectations. Incredibly complex, well balanced and damn quaffable. Subsequent batches have failed to live to the 08.

Bottle. 12 oz. (2010 Vintage) Pours a gloriously deep, sinfully dark root beer brown opaque with absolutely no head; motor-oil slick surface. Aroma is a knock out: caramel, vanilla bean, cinnamon, toffee, chocolate, molasses, maple syrup, brown sugar, roasted malts, marshmallow, coffee beans, and light touches of ginger and honey. Full, luxuriously rich body with a firm, sturdy, boozy palate that slides across the tongue and eases itself warmly down the throat and into the belly. Finishes with insane sweetness and booziness. This is hands down, flat out one of the best beers ever brewed. Classy, strong, bold, and fundamentally well-crafted brew.

Had this on-tap at American Craft in Brookline a couple days ago. Review from notes.

4.0 A: Dark bar, but looks like black with small tan head. Reasonable lacing.

4.5 S: Overwhelming aroma is bourbon, but it is backed up with great complexity. Alcohol, dark crystal sweetness, plum fruitiness, and a touch of tobacco.

4.0 T: Again, bourbon is the strongest component. Taste follows the nose.

4.0 M: Heavier medium body. Would prefer a touch more carbonation. Reasonably smooth with alcohol on finish.

3.5 D: Tasty brew, but the bourbon gets to be a pain as the glass finishes. Due to the insane pricing, I see no reason to ever buy a bottle of this though.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-29-2010 16:35:00
Bottle from Beer Merchants. Dark brown pour, no head. Very vinous aromas of raisins, toffee and caramel. Flavours of coconut, chocolate and vanilla. A little peaty. Fruity, warm and long finish.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2015 Pours dark brown with almost no head. Aroma of ripe fruits, chocolate, bourbon, alcohol and vanilla. Taste is vinous with port notes, dark malts, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, ripe fruits and with a subtle woody end. Also some warming alcohol. Palate is flat and the mouthfeel is dry. excellent.

Poured from 375 ml bottle at Lost Abbey.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, caramel.  Tastes of bourbon, vanilla, caramel.  An amazing beer...one of the best I have had.  Tomme got plenty of grief for the prior vintages that shipped flat.  This one had some carbonation, but who really needs it...this beer is a flavor explosion.

Bottle. Very deep red brown colour with absolutely no head. Aroma is thick with port, brandy, bourbon, sweet liquorice, prunes, deep ripe berries, sugar and candy. Taste is also quite heavy, not boozy though. Lots of port, whisky, bourbon, some faint peat, plums, candy, sugar, tobacco, rum and motor oil. Very full, thorough and nicely intense..

Brown minimal head, oily flat. Aroma is a malt bomb, boubon, vanilla, chocolate, light raisin. Flavor much the same, as it warms, bourbon and chocolate dominate. No carbonation whatsoever, really hurts the score, just enough to brighten it up would work wonders.

750ml bottle poured into tulip. Pours a dark brown with little to no head. Poured a bit flat, medium body. Taste was a bit flat but had some hints of carbonations. Lots of dark fruits in this beer and lots of bourbon, this beer is delicious and one of the better lost abbey brews despite the carbonation problem, it is a barley wine so it does not require much carbo.

2008 vintage 375 ml bottle. Pours a dark chestnut brown color with some mahogany at the edges and topped by a thin layer of tan colored bubbles that settle to a thin film. Sheets of legging stick to the glass. The aroma is really nice showing notes of dark chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, toffee, and vanilla. The barrel imparts subtle hints of oak and smooth bourbon. The flavors follow suit with more of the sweet caramel and toffee, chocolate covered dark fruit, toasted nuts, and the oak laden vanilla. The oak is present and the smooth bourbon ties everything together on the finish. Nearly full bodied, smooth and almost cream with subtle carbonation that leads to a sweet bourbon finish. This is a delicious beer. I was a little worried if it would be flat or not, but this bottle was perfectly carbonated. Another awesome beer from Lost Abbey.

A very interesting beer with lots of complexity. Chocolate and whiskey flavors and aroma. Some smoke and alcohol in the finish. Lightly sweet, but still well balanced. Light carbonation, no head, and extremely heavy and full bodied.

38cl, at 12.5%Vol, as Angels Share (Bourbon 2010 imprinted on the bottle), exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, sweet and heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Bottle. Deep dark ruby red with a thin light colored tan head. Rich caramel and subtle notes of the Bourbon permeate the aroma wafting from this delectable brew. Light carbonation moving though this slightly oaked, mostly malted rich brew. Great for sipping

375mL bottle, shared with McBerko (thanks!). Pours a french roast deep brown, little lingering head. Aroma is truly divine and liqueur like; woodiness is not too sharp or oaky but the best bourbon notes have lingered. More English Xmas pudding qualities with a density and richness that feels like that boozy desert.  Vanilla present too. One of those barley wines that makes you stop talking and just sink into the experience of the palette. Wonderful.

2010 Bottle.  Dark dark brown-red, beige bubbles are quick to disappear.  Aroma is heavy bourbon, vanilla, oak, alcohol.  Taste is heavy malt, slick, raisin, dark fruit, chocolate, then a wash of bourbon vanilla and splintered fresh oak and char.

375mL bottle, split with manuchampions, pours deep dark brown with a reddish hue and pretty much no head. Ultra complex aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, and dark fruits - very boozy. Flavour is also very boozy, packing some serious heat, while revealing a complex mix of bourbon, oak and vanilla - quite liqueur-like. Marginally better than the regular The Angels Share.

Poured from a 375 bottle shared with family on Christmas day, pours a murky brown with a thin head, the aroma is full of toffee, chocolate, raisin and bourbon, theres a ton going on here.  The flavor has a mixture of raisin, bourbon, oak and a hint of booze in the finish.  This is a very drinkable barley wine and I wish I had more!

From summer secret santa 2010.   Aroma and flavor are an intense mixture of bourbon, candied sugar, alcohol, and tons of fruit.  An amazing combination that did not disappoint., however I do prefer the brandy barrel version.  Carbonation was non-existent, but honestly doesnt take much away from the beer overall.  Still full bodied and very smooth.

Shared in Pizza Port bottle shop. This is as about as big as it gets. Full bodied. Lots of raisin and bourbon in the nose. Viscous and warming. A bit one dimensional and gets a bit much after a while, but a great BW none the less. Unsurprisingly lots of booze and a very long warm finish. One to share even in 375 ml bottles.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. This is the Christmas beer for 2010, purchased this fall and stored in much anticipation! :-) Consumed on Christmas Day, but as a stand-alone brew rather than a pairing - I hardly want stout Norwegian Christmas food to interfere with this elegant beauty. Pours a headless, deep brown body with a small maelstrom of bubbles on top, active enough to put any suspicions that this is a dead beer aside. Still, the opaque, retention-devoid surface beckons in a mysterious way. I dip my nose in and immediately get the bourbon flavors: oaky, syrupy, soy-like salt licorice tones, some milk chocolate and roasted malts, flanked with boozy notes and hints of pea- and coconut. Absolutely delicious. The first sip reveals a rather balanced brew, not overtly flavorful, heavy or strong as one could perhaps expect after the initial aroma. Well-toned notes of soy, booze, peanut, roasted malts, hints of peat, red grapes and wood are quite well interwoven, and the massive 12,5 % ABV hardly show at all, except for in the warming aftertaste. Very well made. A bit more carbonation would have helped though, as this beer is very dense and syrupy. Nevertheless, a world-class barley wine, oozing of respect and craftsmanship. A good pick for my Christmas choice this year. Once again, Id like to take the opportunity to wish my fellow beer geeks world wide a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. Cheers! :-D

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2013 375ml bottle in a shaker.  Pours black.  Aroma strong of coffee, toffee, smokiness, chocolate, roasted malts.  Flavor very complex of all of these notes and some alcohol on the finish.  Thick texture.  One of the top 5 beers Ive ever had.
Edit: Pours dark brown.  Aroma of bourbon then all of the other stuff I listed before.  This beer tastes more like bourbon than any other beer.

Pours deep mahogany brown with no head at all. Epic flatness awaits. Aroma is dominated by the bourbon casks, oak indeed, hints of vanilla, liquorice, sweet prunes, dates, dark candy sugar. Taste is immense on the bourbon too. Dry oak, lots of sweet dark fruits, candy sugar as well, pipe tobacco, caramel, hints of vanilla and sweet liquorice. A fait amount of alcohol taste as well. Only a tad of bitterness to balance out the sweetness. Mouthfeel is very thick, almost oily texture and flat as a pancake.

Courtesy Secret Santa. Thanks! Ummmm..I think there was something wrong with this bottle. Aroma was dark fruit and a hint of cardboard. Pour was a nice enough murky and hazy brown with a few tan clouds for a head. Taste was very watery if sipped. Absolutely no carbonation at all. If taking a big gulp I could taste the dark fruit, hints of wood and some roasted malt. Those flavors, when detectable, made the beer drinkable....good even. But there just was not much flavor there otherwise. Is this an infected bottle? Judging from the other ratings it must be. Still decent regardless!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottled 375ml. It pours a beautiful murky nut brown beer with hardly any head at all. Walnuts, vanilla, oak, raisin, caramel and a lot of lovage showing up in the nose.
Faint mocha reminiscence in the taste. Subdued bitterness. Very complex. Practically no carbonation. Full bodied. Great malt profile. Interesting bourbon components which adds character to this beer. Warming on the swallow. Wonderful long finish which is reminiscent of vanilla, caramel, cocoa powder, mint, coconut and lovage. A huge amount of dried apricot and raisin in the late aftertaste.

Again, thanks very much to MesandSim for this. Huge aroma with the knackers to make Buster Gonad blush. Lots of chocolate and caramel, wood, alcohol and a little smoke. Flavour is less of an assault on the senses than the smell but still packing more balls than Wayne Rooneys agent. The money grabbing twat. The barrel aging flavours kick arse. Belter!

Had on tap at tap at Devils Den in Philadelphia

A-pours a murky dark brown with little thin tan colored head.

S-the nose is of bourbon and light wood up front.  A fair bit of chocolate malt and lots of Sweet sugary dark malts come in next.  A fair bit of raisins, dried plums, carmelized brown sugar.

T-follows the nose but more vibrant.  The chocolate malts are more pronounced, fair bit of raisins, wood notes come in with a strong bourbon presence and decent bit of heat.

M-full bodied, creamy and wet, slightly coats the mouth with a lively finish somewhat prickly.

D-slightly bourbon heavy and somewhat hot but nice complexity of malt flavors balanced by a fair bit of sweetness.

2009 Edition shared courtesy of bmanning at a recent tasting.

A: Pours a fairly dark brown with some copper hues to it. No head and no lacing.

S: Lots of delicious bourbon accompanied by vanilla, oak, caramel, and toffee. Hints of fruit in the background.

T: The bourbon is the key player, but is balanced quite well by the oak and caramel sweetness of the malt. Quite intriguing and complex.

M: Almost completely flat, but I didnt have a problem with it at all. The bourbon presence is definitely quite overwhelming, but the alcohol isnt too much--went down very smooth.

D: Very complex with powerful yet complementary flavors; a big hit, and Id love to drink this one again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-10-2010

375ml bottle:  2010 bottling. This one pours a murky, dark brown color.  It appears to be "thicker" than a typical beer, looking more viscous when it pours.  There is absolutely no head on it, and really no carbonation to speak of either. You could call it "still".  Very nice aroma.  Bourbon is up front.  I also get notes of chocolate and raisins, as well as some other fruits.  Vanilla and  brown sugar also.  What a succulent taste.  A bit of bourbon and alcohol on the top.  Lots of other flavors combining to form an exquisite combination. It is really rich and silky on the tongue.  It may be a bit pricey, but it is definitely worth the money.  Ill be buying this again (and again).

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2010 375 ml bottle from zenwolf shared with jsprime. pours murky maroon with a scant off white head. minimal carbonation, but hey at least there was some! nose of bourbon, booze deep fruity malt. huge flavour of bourbon and malt. soft subtle and complex. outstanding. i want more of this.

Bottle 2008 vintage. Bourbon in the nose with some caramel notes. More of a cordial than a beer. Since its called Angels Share i decided to share it... with McBeer. Warming like a bourbon but with the malt profile of a beer. Very good.

Shared by Bigmmartin.  Heavy sweet bourbon aroma with roasty dark fruit and vanilla.  Great body and sweet flavor with dry alcohol hitting at the end.  Ive got to knock it down a few on palate/appearance/overall due to the near complete lack of carbonation.  I knew it was possible, but its still annoying.

At Schous Mikrobryggeri, Grünerlökka, Oslo. Stunningly complex aroma with distinct hints of cocoa and cherries and some typical bourbon features. Basically no foam whatsoever. Taste is complex, dry and a tad winy, containing chocolate, vanilla and bourbon character from the barrels.
Bottle.  Big bourbon and dark fruit aromas.  Pour is mahogany brown with barely any head.  Carbonation seems to be ok.  Lush dark fruits, bourbon, caramel malts, vanilla, and port flavors...

Picked up this much often talked about beer in San Diego.  Nice that Olive Tree Marketplace had this; I wasnt expecting it.  Pours a deep brown with literally less than 1 mm head.  Normally low carbonation levels are a turn off for me in beers.  In this one, however, it didnt bother me one bit, because the flavor was so complex, yet so smooth.  Bourbon, vanilla, just a tad bit tart, port wine like.  Really well made, no matter what all of the haters say.  Im glad I purchased this.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2011 2008 Bottle. Pours dark, amber-brown with a soft, off-white head. Lots of dark, ripe fruits in the aroma, along with alcohol, malts and light toffee. Sweet flavor with plenty of malts, fruits, wood and caramel. Medium in body with average carbonation. The beer finishes sweet with some lingering boozy warmth. Nice.
Roasty, nutty, a bit of caramel and toffee.  Prominent whiskey tones, strong oak presence, vanilla flavors in the aftertaste.  Smooth as my babys bottom.

I had the pleasure of sampling this at the Strong Ale Fest at Avery Brewing and at the Lost Abbey 4th Anniversary party.

Dark brown color with small head. The aroma is alcohol bourbon with carmel, toffee notes. Sweet bourbon malty taste with alcohol and vanilla. Alcohol warmth. Medium body. A very pleasant experience that tipped off my tasting at the 4th Anniversay party. The rest is a haze.

I like the smell of bourbon, so it stands to reason that I like the smell of this beer. Lots of bourbon, good notes of vanilla and caramel, which is also apparent in the taste. Nice bourbon and malty sweetness, with a surprisingly crisp finish. Nicely carbonated, too, btw. 2008 vintage sampled in 2010.

The aroma is potent, very malty barleywine. The apprarance is dark amber with a bit of a ruby hue. The flavor of a smooth barleywine with vague coffee note. The body is raw and boozy, especially from the barrel aging.

375 ml bottle

Finding this in the back of the cellar with a few other beers to save for later I decided to crack it open. After a run of more mundane stuff I was craving something brash and bold. A Top 50 worthy barley wine aged in bourbon seemed like just the ticket and it met all my expectations. This is marginally better than the brandy alternative (which was no slouch itself). Were it not $20 Id probably try to trade for more.

Aroma / Appearance - Carbonated with a dense blackish brown body the lacing was like a thin film of plastic. Vanilla, oak, heavy dark chocolate, and plum made this so rich I almost reached for a spoon. It was so good that I spent over ten minutes just soaking in the aroma before daring to take a sip.

Flavor / Palate - Chocolate truffles, vanilla, and a finger of bourbon create a dessert like texture. Thick and creamy this can chewed if you like to really take your time. Fig sneaks in after a few sips to add even more enjoyment. The alcohol is well balanced. Obviously you cant hide 12.5% but you can do what Port has done and add enough flavor that it doesnt dominate. A tingling bitterness sits in the throat after everything else is done soaking in. This is truly a world class beer.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share. Pours a dark red/brown with no head. Even with a vigorous pour. The aroma has a tun of bourbon. Thats pretty much all I can smell. The flavor brings oak, coconut, vanilla, chocolate, tannin, and a long bitter finish. Only just a hint of carbonation. The barrel realy takes away from the complexity of this beer. It really is too bad.

Pours black. No head. Aroma is amazing, bold malty, you can really smell te bourbon barrel. Bold malty flavour, very sweet. Whiskey and vanilla. Chocolate, dark fruits and roasted malts. This is a great beer very bold very complex. This is a perfect barrel aged beer!

Bottle, thanks to Doodler, whose cellar full of amazing beer, and crazy generosity just stagger the mind. Pours very dark, opaque brown, no head, no lacing. Obviously a Lost Abbey product, because the carbonation BLOWS! Nose is fantastic, though, rich multi-layered bourbon, so much sweet bourbon and vanilla, caramel, just rich and cake-like and fantastic. Flavours are mildly boozy, with syrup, and bourbon, and booze, layered with creme caramel, chocolate fudge, so powerful, and yet the booze doesnt interfere. Fantastic stuff, just wish it was carbonated.

Big thanks to Kirk Diggler for hooking me up with this bottle. Ive been hunting down Lost Abbey beers ever since I was lucky enough to get Serpents Stout, so I was very excited to try this one, even though Im not a big fan of barley wines. The color is almost a muddy brown shade, with a very thin off white foam head. The aroma is somewhat musty with various hints of bourbon, malts, and alcohol, with a slight burn in the nose. Its quite light on the tongue and goes down really easy. The flavors are exactly what the aromas suggest, bourbon, malts, and alcohol. Hopefully I can get some more Lost Abbey in the future.

damn this was smooth. actually was more unique than the brandy barrel, which was surprising given the plethora of BB beers out there. not sickly sweet like some of those, though. GREAT sipper...tobacco, fig, vanilla...quite complex and ridiculously smooth."

Bouteille de 375 ml, chez Dany et Marie-France. Arômes très intenses de bourbon, de chêne et de vanille. Belle présence de chocolat. Robe brune foncée et opaque, très faible effervescence (mais présente), aucune mousse. En bouche, le caramel brûlé et le chocolat accompagnent le chêne et la vanille. Le bourbon, moins présent lorsque la bière est froide, se manifeste graduellement lorsquelle se réchauffe. Très corpulente et sucrée, il sagit dune bière dessert particulièrement décadente. Finale sucrée et légèrement alcoolisée. Très bon !

Bottle from Foodery II.   Pour into a snifter.   Dark burgendy hued appearance... a bit more off white foam atop than the original.  Rich malt, whiskey, and vanilla in the nose.   Bourbon isnt overwhelming but it adds a great addition to one of the most complex brews Ive had the pleasure of drinking.  Maple, vanilla, bourbon, sweet malt, molasses.   Ultra bright - buttery and doughy.   Epic.

From old notes.  An interesting and complex beer but it doesnt quite work for me.  The base beer seems quite enjoyable.  Its like a big barleywine with some deeper roast and dark fruit notes.  Theres more going on in there than I can quite describe, but the bourbon flavor seemed to overpower some of this complexity.  It has raisins, brown sugar, molasses, vanilla, bourbon, oak and even mild coffee and chocolate.  This version just didnt come together for me as much as the Grand Cru.  Its not quite a mess, but the alcohol heat was a bit much and the bourbon flavor sort of threw things out of whack more than it blended the flavors into a harmony.  For bourbon barrel barleywines, Ill take FW Parabola, AS Grand Cru and even Marins -bal Old Dipsea.  I would have preferred this beer aged in a neutral oak barrel or perhaps just less time in the bourbon.  Its still rather good - hard to dislike a beer with so many interesting layers to it.  Mouthfeel is a bit sticky (and some bottles probably arent carbonated properly but my notes are from the keg version).  Interesting beer and I may revisit this rating once I try a future version.

12.7 oz bottle purchased from BevMo in laguna, CA, labeled Bourbon 20 - Cork pops with little to know pressure. Pours a nearly opaque ruby red color with basically no head. Aroma is loaded with somewhat hot bourbon, very chewy caramel, oaky tannins, vanilla, raisens, red grapes, touch of chocolate and coffee beans, touch of cherries. Flavor is very oaky, with lots of bourbon, vanilla, raisens, hints of coffee, loads of chewy caramel. palate is thick, lagubrious. This is very interesting, very delicious. A brooding, thoughtful brew.

Bottle from Lost Abbey (2010). Pours prune juice color with a few bubbles. Dark aromas of plum/raisin, bourbon? and wood. Thick bodied with very light carbonation. Theres heat, and a lot of bourbon?/oak/vanilla. Then the dark fruit comes out, followed by some heavy malt. It doesnt seem very complex, until it sits in the mouth and one wonders "what is that?" Nice change from beer aged in single malt scotch barrels. Apparently the barrel would be Bernheim Original Straight Wheat Whiskey which may not exactly result in Bourbon, but it seems close to that.  But different. Nice!
Bottle from 08 thanks to daknole. Pours a brown color with no carbonation. Has a woody bourbon smell. Has a nutty, bourbon, vanilla, wood and some booze in the taste. A bit over rated if you ask me

(Bottled, sampled 2010-03-02) Very dark brown with hardly any head. Whisky-like alcohol in the nose, with neutral-toffeish maltiness and dried fruit. Sweetish, grainy malt in the flavor, with dried fruit and not much alcohol. Quite full body, warming palate, low in CO2. Quite different from the regular version, with almost no alcohol, and less sweetness.

Flaske årgang 2009 750 ml: Absolut ingen karbonation på denne øl hvilket er så pisse ærgeligt t det gør ondt. Rødbrun klar farve. Duft af portvin og bourbon med en sødlig molasse der ligger under de andre dufte. Smagen er også helt i top, hvor fadlagringen og integrationen af bourbon er uforlignelig. Desværre er det hele en kende messy grundet den manglende karbonation. Øv.

Bottle from South Bay.  New packaging; 375ml 2010 release.  Light pop of the cork; very dark brown color.  A vigorous pour produces a ultra thin head that fades off to the sides rather quickly.  Just like the brandy version the aroma here is quite nice; caramel, strong bourbon, plums, licorice, toffee, oak, molasses.  The flavors are very rich; heavy caramel and toffee malt.  Prunes, figs, and plums provide the dark fruity element.  The bourbon is strong, and is the vehicle for this tasty beer, but its not overdone and provides some nice soothing warmth.  The carbonation is good with this one.  This is really really good stuff.

Bottle thanks to Scott! Pours near black with no head to speak of. Aroma is quite boozy with a strong bourbon note and a backing burnt caramel and sweet bread note. Flavor begins dark grains but sweetens quite quickly with caramel and a strong bourbon note in the finish and after taste. Beer lacked a bit of carbonation, but it didnt hurt the beer by any means.

Body is chestnut-black, and garnet-black at the very edges. head was thin and foamy, a dark burnt sienna, short and quick.  Aroma is like a barley wine, - vinuous sweet sherry, oak, light vanilla, and bourbon. also prune aroma, very sweet. Flavor is a strong and sweet syrupy malt, but not at all sticky. lively carbonation and a bourbony sweet sherry flavor that builds into a slow burn. a little charred oakyness and faintly smoky. some prune and bitter hoppyness in the finish. spicy aftertaste. ASA or barley wine? definitely from the west coast but the style is debatable.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark, dark brown. Slight mahogany hues around the edges. No head, skim, foam, residue, lacing etc. Perfectly still looking.

S: Massive bourbon blast. Roasted malts. Oak and vanilla.

T: The taste is a different story as the bourbon really overpowered all the subtle flavors that make bourbon barrel-aged beers special. I just couldnt find the things that could have made this beer special.

M: Lightly carbonated (but in a good way). Nice booze burn at 12%.

O: In the end, there is just too much bourbon coming through in the flavor to make this more than a once in a blue moon beer. It took me quite a bit of time to finish my five ounce pour. Glad to get this on the cheap as opposed to shelling out for a big bottle that Id struggle to finish.

Draft at Toronado (only 3$ by the way).  Deep foreboding black with the thinnest of heads.  Full spectrum of aroma, deep charred out snokiness with a sturdy fruit presence, cherry chocolate vanilla and oak.  Flavor are mouthfeel are transcendent.  The depth and complexity are sublime and its perfectly balanced power and sweetness shocked me.  Warmth of roasted toasty caramel/sweet fruit/ smoked melange of flavor is otherwordly.  I just had to put my notes down and enjoy this one.   One of the best beer experiences I have ever had

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2012 Just about the only way to improve the angels share. More the oak flavor rounds out the character of the finish to give it a more alcoholic flavor. Very nice addition to the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2011 (375 ml bottle from El Cerrito).  Pours dark brown/caramel color with a thin khaki head.  Moderate carbonation bubbles.  Aroma has bourbon, rich, buttery caramel, and some wood.  Taste is sweet with bourbon and caramel malts coming through.  Full bodied with a slick, oily texture.  Smooth finish. This is a fantastic beer.

375 mL bottle.  Pours deep, murky brown with no head.  Strong, complex aroma with molasses, dark fruit, cocoa, bourbon, toffee, caramel.  Very nice.  Flavor has lots of cocoa and molasses up front, bourbon, dark fruit, oak, caramel.  Tiny alcohol burn.  Needless to say, great job.

Pours deep reddish brown, thin to no tan head.  Aroma is some smoke, bourbon, and chocolate.  Taste is chocolate and roast up front, nice bourbon and smoke in the middle ending roasted and dry.  Nice touch of carbonation, not flat, and delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2010 Bottle compliments of mothman. Pours a pitch black brown with minimal head or carbonation. The aroma is of bourbon, dark malt, and vanilla, with some boozy notes. The first sip and it is evident this was aged in bourbon barrels as that is the first thing that comes to mind. After that the taste is sweet with notes of licorice, dark fruit, and chocolate. Med/Heavy mouthfeel. Very tasty but I am not sure why it is classified as a Barley Wine on this site as it is an American Strong Ale
Pours dark deep brown with off-white head. Very low carbonation. Tons of bourbon and roasted malt on the nose. Mouthfeel is very smooth, flavor is boozy and finishes sweet.

Pours a lovely burgundy in the glass. No head. Nose is bourbon, roasted coffee, smoked wood, oak and butterscotch. Taste is sweet caramel, pleasant, but very strong bourbon, smoke, wood, oak and almonds.

On draft at the P.O.P.E. in South Philadelphia.  At this high an alcohol level and with such a strong bourbon flavor its easy to understand the fuss over this beer.  It compares to Founders Backwoods Bastards but is even more concentrated and intense.  Virtually no carbonation and a thick, viscous body this really is a beer to be sipped slowly as a final beer in a session.  The caramel flavor is there, but the bourbon really predominates in an amazing way (and I"m not even a bourbon-lover).

Fløska, courtesy of Pinball. Deep deep dark brown colour, no head. Sweet dark fruity spiced bitter roasty malty woody caramel alco aroma, with chocolate. Pleasant sticky mouthfeel. The flavour has lots of dark fruits, caramel, roasty malt, wood, alc., chocolate and some whisky.

On tap @ Choice City Butcher & Deli in Fort Collins, Co. Pours a deep rusty copper with a dense beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, wood, Bourbon, alcohol and vanilla. The flavor is mostly sweet malt and dark fruit but with a warming Bourbon taste and some dry wood. Fullish body with a mild carbonation and smooth full mouth feel. Glad I got a chance to try this and was happy it was carbonated ;). So smooth and good.

On tap.  Pours a slightly cloudy dark brown with minimal head.  Nose is complex awesomeness.  Sweet with malt, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, alcohol, dark dried fruit - some raisins, prunes.  Full-bodied, initial sweetness with lots of vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit.  Alcohol slowly building throughout, but its never too much.  Finishes long, more alcohol and bourbony vanilla goodness.  I love what theyve done with this - a great beer to sip on.

pours a dark brown with a very little khaki head, and good lacing.

smell is of bourbon, wood, alcohol, and dark fruit.

taste is strong alcohol, cocoa, and dark fruit, ends with a potent alcohol taste and somewhat dry.

Pours deep mahogany into a snifter. Off-white micro head with medium retention recedes to skim surface and hug rim. Dark, bourbon soaked dried pit fruit aromas. Thick and hot with upfront bourbon and cherries turning to chocolate and vanilla vapors in the lasting finish. A lot of nice burn to this one.

pitch dark, almost no head.
roasted and very woody notes, vineous, toffee, chocolate.
flavor of toffee, sweet licorice, caramel, sweet malts, pretty well balanced but too much toffee for me. also vanilla, booze. winey notes (probably the wood).
faint licorice in there too. ends  woody, licorice, toffee..

0,375 l bottle (vintage 2008) at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Dark reddish brown color. Thick aroma with raisins, chocolate, oak, vanilla and warming alcohol. Thick sweet and acidic flavor with oak, chocolate, tart fruitiness, raspberry, cherry, raisins and soya sauce. Full body with tannic mouthfeel, feels like fruit skins. Very warming. Tasty sippin beer.

Shared at a local BA tasting -- Dark brown, faint head.  Intense vanilla-wood and bourbon aromas ride thick waves of dark fruits and sweet rich caramel.    Deep bourbon and oak notes round well with thick rich toffee- plum and raisin tone throughout.  Full bodied, cask-like carbonation, boozy warming finish. A great sipper that could pair with a robust cigar at any time
Smells like the bourbon. Also lots of vanilla aroma added to it. I also tasted caramel and coconut. Dark brown in color. Had on tap. A very good beer.

2008 bottle shared by ryan.  Pours a thick opaque pour with a red tinge.  Tan head floats on top with nice lacing in the glass.  Strong aroma of raisins, chocolate, and bourbon.  Lots of roasted malt.  Sweet flavor with roast chocolate and raisins.  Bourbon throughout with a creamy finish.  Slightly bitter end.  Very heavy.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 375mL bottle, 2008 vintage, courtesy of ryan, rated 5/22/2010.  9/5/8/4/16 Pours a deep dark brown, poured slowly to mitigate the carbonation a bit.  Lots of tan head.  Aroma is sweet raisins, chocolate, bourbon, and a touch of alcohol.  The bourbon is less apparent in the flavor than I expected based on the aroma.  Taste is reasonably sweet with very little harshness, with lots of malt and chocolate, some bourbon, and alcohol.  A touch of oxidation.  Finish is somewhat bitter with roasty malt.


375mL bottle, 2010 vintage, rated 5/22/2010.  9/5/7/4/15  Looks the same as the 08 vintage, with less carbonation.  Small noise as the cork is popped.  Much more alcohol and bourbon in this batch than the 08, theres a mild burn on the nose, and some heat going down the throat.  Behind the alcohol and bourbon lies chocolate, roasted malt, and sweet raisin.  A bit too boozy, but other than that a good beer.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Rating # 600 2009 Bottle thanks to Ryan (Giascar) pours dark brown with a very minamal head  flat who fu--ing cares the aromas are from sweet borubon that tantalize your senses with every wiff more aromas leap into your nostrils vanilla,earthy oak,toffee,and huge malts taste of all with the malt back bone of the incredible hulk a great barly wine the lack of carbonation doesnt effect the taste so stop whining sit back and sip this one and enjoy

Few bubbles, no carb, brown in color, darksih, and cloudy.  The smell is bourbon, alcohol, malts, caramel, toffee, and wood. The taste is much of the same as the smell with the wood and alcohol coming out even more. Good with a nice finsh.

No date...  A very minimal, tan head which is fully diminishing; color is a dark mocha.  Nose is pleasant and potent with toffee, burnt caramel, lots of vanilla, notable sweet oak, dates, maybe some molasses, warming alcohol, and dark candi sugar.  Flavor is much of the same notes with less bourbon notes than the I would have thought, knowing how the original tasted; lightly charred oak, some sweet Bourbon oak, Belgian chocolate, toffee, vanilla, dark candi sugar, and hints at raisins.  Palate is full, lightly syrupy, round, soft, and very warm.  Finishes fairly long, still warm with sweet bourbon, and notes of toffee, vanilla, and charred oak.  It was no surprise that I liked this one better than the original being a bourbon drinker, and I believe this is a 2008 bottle since 2009 is not printed on the bottle.  I still think I might like this more with age, but nevertheless, it was better on bourbon and still an interesting beer.

Dark plum, raisin, date, and smoothed out sweet, bourbon aroma.   Dark black/brown in the glass with a slight, scattered head and some minimal carbonation.  So smooth.  Bourbon flavor is extremely well integrated and allows the other notes (fruit, thinning alcohol, oak, muddled licorice) to present.   Thick, dark notes on the taste falling into a pleasant alcohol tinge with a bourbon presence.  This beer really kicks ass and has opened my mind even further to bourbon-aged beers.  Definite repurchase (and come to think of it a rerate of the Brandy is called for as well).

A: A dark brown color with a slight muddiness to it and a medium tan head.

S: Very strong and pleasant vanilla aroma along with some mild oak, toffee, and a heavy chocolate. The bourbon is warming and inviting.

T: The alcohol is not overwhelming at all, despite a strong bourbon presence in the nose (and a pronounced flavor). The vanilla, chocolate, toffee, and molasses carry the beer and work wonderfully with the booze and oak.

M: A full bodied beer to say the least with adequate (low to moderate) carbonation.

D: I have a hard time choosing which I like better, the brandy or the bourbon. But luckily both of them are generally available and neither is a bad choice.
375ml courtesy of @bikesandbeers.  Pours syrupy with a big head that goes away with time.  Smells like boozy raisins.  Sweet and thick with a little bite on the back of the tongue at the end.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2015 Bottle split with Pat, Zahra and Tony. Pours a dark, dark thick raisin-red-black body, no head, no lacing - syrupy body. Aroma is insanely delicious and complex - notes of vanilla extract, bourbon, chocolate, molasses.  Mouthfeel is silky texturized with flavors of vanilla, molasses, chocolate, slight bourbon.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a gloriously deep, sinfully dark root beer brown opaque with absolutely no head; motor-oil slick surface. Aroma is a knock out: caramel, vanilla bean, cinnamon, toffee, chocolate, molasses, maple syrup, brown sugar, roasted malts, marshmallow, coffee beans, and light touches of giner and honey. Full, luxuriously rich body with a firm, sturdy, boozy palate that slides across the tongue and eases itself warmly down the throat and into the belly. Finishes with insane sweetness and booziness. This is hands down, flat out one of the best beers ever brewed. Classy, strong, bold, and fundamentally well-crafted brew. Perfect.
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2010 Had with James and pat. Pour is dark thick brown. Aroma is vanilla caramel and malts. Flavor is Bourbon caramel and vanilla.

Poured from a 12.7 oz. bottle into an Old Stock glass. Appearance is a dark brown with a thin head that quickly dissipated. Major bourbon taste, with hints of vanilla in the taste. You gotta like boozy to enjoy this, which I do. This is a sipper, as it bathes in the 12.5% abv!

From a [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Abbey 4th Anniversary,Coconut,Chocolate,vanilla.I usually dont like burbon in my beer but this is a great example how good a beer w/Bourbon is .

2009 375 bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Ive always been more inclined towards the bourbon over the brandy, and this confirms that.  Pours a clear but very dark burnt brown color with basically no head or carbonation... mmmm.  Aroma is strong of bourbon, woody fresh oak, some vanilla and coconut, and lots of fruity tootsie-roll.  Flavor is bright of fresh woody oak, bright oak flavor, lesser vanilla, strong bourbon, almost harsh, lessor raisin, tootsie-roll, bourbon is quite strong but works better IMO with the base beer than the brandy, a harsh booziness in the finish but Im a sucker for bourbon and this is framed very well, could probably have used another 1 year in the bottle, but still way better than the brandy.  Seems more attenuated than the brandy, less viscous and way easier to drink, zero carbonation but Im fine with that.  I think Ill still prefer Wooden Hell or Harvest lagavulin, but this is basically just as good, I just dont like the brandy for some reason.

No foam. Flat.

Aroma: Raisins, OAK! Smoke. Amazing balance of sweet vs. oak.

Taste: Watery, no hint of alcohol, balanced in the middle, but in a boring way.

Palate: Flat, medium-full - thinner than expected. Smooth finish. Like a soft wine. 

 Weird mix of amazing aroma, and boring taste/appearance/palate. Could be a soft wine.

Purchased in Ølbutikken.

Pours deep brown with a very small head. Aroma of raisins, musty Belgian yeast, and oak. Flavor is dominated by oak, to an unpleasant degree. Mouthfeel is rich but clunky (i.e., no carbonation). If this is the future of beer, you can count me out.

750ml from 2009 courtesy of Charlie. Pours a still brown. No head, very little carbonation. Nose is a face smacking array of caramel, vanilla, leather and smoke and a hint of cherry chocolate cake. Flavor is intense chocolate cake with hints of maraschino cherry, bourbon figures in heavily but is not overdone. A lingering vanilla note carries through to the caramel laden finish. The chocolate cake lingers on the tongue for a long while. Terrific. A little carbonation would have improved the score for the sake of appearance and Ill admit that since its flat, this one is a sipper and you can feel the alcohol. The carbonation would help the drinkability. Still a great beer even flat.

Draught. Boulder Strong Fest 2010. Black/brown with thin tan head. Coco powder and booze and smelly feet covered with clean socks, biscuity butterscotch and whiskey. Flavor is coco and booze and sweet booze. Chocolate syrupy and hops and sticky leaving burnt taste.

Bottle shared with jimbowood.  Pours brown with bubbly off white head.  Aroma of oak, bourbon, and vanilla.  Taste has huge bourbon notes with vanilla and chocolate.  Very smooth with thick mouthfeel.  Mild alcohol burn in the finish.  Awesome beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 Looks just like prune juice and smells like sweet milk chocolate liqueur. Flavor is a sweet chewy chocolate malt with a very complex bourbon hotness running just underneath. No wonder this #1  in style. Hot damn. Bottle purchased from the brewery.
Another amazing lost abbey brew. Black body with large beige head. Aroma of caramel, chocate, bourbon/oak and slight booze. Flavor of caramel, toffee, sweet oaky finish. Creamy, enveloping mouthfeel

2010 375ml. pours with good carb, not a lot, but a proper amount in appearance and body for this beer. dark brown pour, oily looking, lots of lacing and spotting, head is full, maybe 1/4 inch, a more vigerous pour could net more im sure, if thats your goal. aroma is nice, but is def a lil heavy on the bourbon. i like it, smells delicious to me, but the great odor of the beer is masked. it comes through much better and more balanced in the flavor, though still heavy on the bourbon. just a tingle of heat, very pleasant slightly numbing effect. the bourbon, caramel, and roast flavors all dominate, and do it well. good stuff.

2008 375ml bottle - 

Aroma - vanilla and bourbon really jump out at me on the initial sniff.  Raisins, oak, light brown sugar/raw sugar, and black cherry ice cream.

Appearance - body looked like something drained from a rusty gutter...cloudy, muddy brown mixed with brick red, creamy light tan 1/2" head...plenty of carbonation.  

Taste - Perfect.  An excellent balance of bourbon character with a perfect barleywine.  Neither overwhelmes the other, and in fact the bourbon just accentuates the barleywine notes.  Incredibly complex with bounding notes of vanilla ice cream, bourbon, toasted oak, raisin puree with cherries, toffee...beautiful.  

Palate - Creamy, slightly biting, medium bodied with thickness to match, fairly sticky from the sugars.

Overall - Well worth the wait and opening on a special occasion (my 14th wedding anniversary) will be worth remembering.

Bottled 375 ml @Pikkulintu
Deep ruby color, not much head, just some off-white foam. Aroma has berries, cellar, some sourness, vanilla and oak. Very smooth and soft palate. Complex flavor has cherry, berries, bretta, vanilla, toffee, bourbon and alcohol. Long fruity, a bit cellary aftertaste. Extremely complex. smooth and warming.
Bottle at Dahlberg. Poors dark brown with no head. Alkohol, choklate, soy, sour in a bad way sweet vanilla woody.Taste Sweet and sour with raisin figs dark fruit rum choklate vanilla boubon.

375 mL, 2009 vintage from lb4lbs liquidation extravaganza (1 of 3)- served in shaker- poured an almost opique extremely dark brown/black with a hint of ruby tint when held to a light source, zero carbonation (alas, the dreaded flat bottle), sat very still in the glass.  Aroma of whisky (not whiskey), malt, and dark fruit- all very restrained, except for the alcohol.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, some malt, some booze- but let it sit.  Let it wait.  The nothingness after the swallow after a "good minute" slowly lets a wave of vanilla come in.  This sensation transcends to moderate tobacco, then hard molasses.  The finish runs forever, and there is not stop.  If I could create a beer that finished like this, I would rule the world.  If I could create a beer with some many levels on the finish, (CENSORED) - their heads would explode (Oh yeah, its that bad!!!  Bad is in DAMN, not bad as in bad).  This beer is strictly for those that can wait for a beer to come into play- 2 oz. beerpayners, please disregard this notice and mark how you are told.  Those of us that are still independent in thought and heart- and there arent many here thats left, ENJOY!!!

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2010 Traded 375mL bottle from 2008 (yeah carbonation!). Enjoyed while my husband sat in an ice bath after finishing the Showdown at Sundown Triathlon. Beer crept out of the bottle before pouring and made a big, brown pillowy head. Pretty nice looking beer, dark murky brown with a thick head. Aroma was tons of dark fruit, rum/bourbon, toasted nuts, caramel malt and some woodiness.  The flavour was more of the same and very similar to the brandy version. Actually left a sweet, sticky film on my lips. I honestly think I liked the brandy version a touch better because there seemed a little too much "bourbon barrel goodness" for me. Still good but maybe over-the-top for my palate.

Bottle shared generously by footbalm, thanks again man 
Appearance: Poured dark burgundy, no head or lacing. No carbonation 
Aroma: Dark malts and fruits, bourbon and chocolate 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel. Hot alcohols, dark malts, bourbon, vanilla 
A nice beer

375 ml bottle shared by shigadeyo.  Thanks Craig!  Pours a deep copper/reddish brown color with a medium-large tan head.  The aroma is that of thick caramel malts, dark ripe fruits, bourbon and oak, with some alcohol that lets you know this is no session beer.  The flavor is big rich caramel malt, ripe dark fruits, brown sugar, well crafted bourbon, vanilla, and some woodiness.  The finish is sweeter with noticeable wood and bourbon influences.  Medium-full bodied and smooth.  This for the most part lived up to the hype for me.
Had at RBWG 2010.  Awesome bourbon barrel characteristics in this, vanilla, caramel, wood, general awesomeness.  Really good... seriously.
RBWG 2010. Pours dark brown with thin off white head. Aromas of bourbon and caramel. Sweet molasses and bourbon flavors. Medium body with soft carbonation.

Draft at Brouwers Hard Liver 08. Poured a deep, dark brown with hints of red and absolutely no head. The nose is intoxicating; chocolate, oak, vanilla, toffee, caramel, and bourbon. The taste is a big bang of vanilla, oak, rum soaked cherry, toffee, bourbon, and some dark chocolate. Palate is smooth, no carbonation at all, and no lacing. This is one of my favorite beers ive ever tried (next to its brandy barrel brother). Wonderful.

2009 bottle thanks to STLWill.  Dark brown pour, no carbonation (not even a slight pop on the cork) and awesome chocolatey bourbon aroma.    Flavor was strong bourbon, caramel, vanilla and a tiny bit of alcohol on the finish.  This definitely got better as it warmed, and is worthy of the acclaim.

Bottle. 2009 Vintage.

Pours a very dark brown, almost opaque. No head whatsoever. 

The aroma is a bit restrained due to the obvious lack of carbonation, but its still quite impressive with smooth bourbon notes on top of toffee, nuts, oak and vanilla. Lovely hints of vinous fruits. 

The flavor is sweet and warming. Perfect integration between the bourbon and the malty backbone. Notes of vanilla, nuts and oak blend wonderfully with caramel malts, toffee and leather. Ends warming with notes of alcohol, bourbon and dried fruits.

Full-bodied and smooth but it feels a bit dull in the mouth as it is as flat as [insert something that makes a dirty joke out of this].

Pours deep murky brown with tan head. The aroma has malts mixing with oak and mild sweet bourbon and mild sweet and dark roasted malts as well as dark fruity esters nearing the end of the draw. The taste comes across first with sweet malt and sweet bourbon then aged oak and sweet vanilla. The vanilla note really seems to take over toward midway. Very nice offering with rich creamy goodness washing across my palate depositing bourbon, vanilla, oak and mild dark fruitiness into the finish.

Everything about this entity is golden.  I mean you take something that is GREAT and put it in bourbon barrels...you only of course get something that is even GREATER!!!  Fantastic brew.  Not overwhelming in any points, completely heady and well aged in those barrels.  YUM to the 10th!!

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Rating #1900. 2008.  Rating from DLD 08. Cloudy brown body, large fizzy tan head; extremely overcarbonated, but is ok once the beer breathes for 30 minutes or so. Big bourbon nose with lots of coconut, toffee and dark fruit. Moderately sweet, moderately bitter with coconut, bourbon, toffee and prunes. Full body is soft, and sticky, with moderate carbonation and a slightly warm finish. Really great beer which Ive enjoyed multiple times since. 8/4/9/4/16 = 4.1 Rerate of 2008, 5/22/2010. After two years, this is definitely picking up quite a bit of oxidation. The malts are dull and the body is syrupy. This one doesnt have much longer until it completely falls apart. 7/4/7/4/15 = 3.7  2010 vintage, 5/22/2010. Wow, after the 2008, the nose on this is really fresh and bright, nice bourbon character, and some nice roastiness. Holy fucking hot boozebomb. This stuff might be 12.5%, but it tastes like 30%. Besides the blazing inferno of alcohol and bourbon, lots of dark fruit, light roast, coconut, molasses. Its also worthy to note that it does have a very nice, light carbonation, that could not be confused with being flat. 8/4/6/4/14 = 3.6

Bottle.  I have waited many moons to crack this, and now that coyotehunter has made his spring migration, the day has come.  First, I would like to thank the folks at Lost Abbey for fixing a previous problem by sending this... class act, guys.  Second, I would confirm the assessment that there is no carbonation, but it has absolutely no impact on my thoughts on this beer...  I think carbonation would be a distraction given what unfolds.  Pours a fairly dark brown with dense aromas of raisins, chocolate, toffee, and... as it warms... bourbon.  I didnt pick it up much right out of the bottle, but 5 minutes later and it hits you in the face.  Flavor is heavy with sticky sweet brown sugar and raisin.  Alcohol is big and leaves a nice warmth in the belly and across the palate in the aftertaste.  World class stuff.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle shared by MrBunn. Pours thick and brown with a heavy aroma of bourbon yet no head and very slick looking. Flavor is a hint of chocolate, rolos, caramel, and and DAMN lot of raisin and dark fruit, heavy on the Bourbon. Quite tasty, but at times the bourbon is a bit overwhelming.

2008 bottle.  I held on to this hoping the carbonation would come up, but no such luck...  Pour was a really dark brown with a tiny off white film.  Aroma was really awesome, lots of oak, vanilla, and bourbon, with some mild dark fruit aromas as well.  Taste is similarly bourbony, with more dark fruit, some big malty sweetness, and some faint warming booze in the finish.  Mouth wasnt great, kind of like cough syrup.  No carb and very sticky.  Overall, a nice brew that would be great with a little fizz.

(Bottle, 2008 vintage, at Pikkulintu) Poured very deep and almost clear with very small and light brown head. Aroma contained malts, wood, alcohol and vineousness. Palate was full bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, vineousness, alcohol, mild vanilla, wood and low bitterness. Balanced. Aftertaste was malty and mildly bitter.

Pours a deep dark ruby and no head whatsoever from the 750ml. bottle purchased at Port Brewing/Lost Abbey Brewing Co. (San Marcos, CA): Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, cherry, oak, soy, toasty caramel, raisins, and dates. At first sip theres a pronounced bourbon bite and a little toasted caramel, raisins, and brown sugar. No carbonation, which probably accentuated the warming alcohol finish. The balance is a little off, in my opinion, due to a lack of alcohol masking. Drinkability: Sip her, for sure. Pairing: aged goat or gorgonzola cheese. Rebuy: Probably. Its really strong. #295 on 25022010, DG.

750ml bottle sampled at Sexual Chocolate Day 2010.  Watery, opaque black, zero head.  Aroma is mostly oak and vanilla and bourbon but thats about it.  Flavor is all booze, bourbon, sweet, brown sugar, molasses.  Finish is hot and boozy.  Too much, no finesse.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2013 Some time in 08: Bottle arrived on the doorstep this afternoon. Perhaps I should have let it sit, but....

Cork pops with a whoosh and the beer bubbles up but doesnt overflow. It pours a deep luxurious walnut brown with an ample tan head, leaving rainbows of lace along the sides of my glass. The aroma is simply divine, a sure 10. Rich caramels meld with -- rather than being overlaid by -- deep bourbon aromas, true vanilla and oak rather than brash young burnt oak chips, dates and pecan pie, lovely.

After the relatively sweet aroma, the flavor startles -- not nearly as sweet as I expected, actually some mild sour notes, a bourbon richness that is so beautifully melded its like no other bourbon aged beer Ive ever tasted. This is to other BA beers as fresh wild strawberries are to strawberry starburst.

Id meant to add to my description as I savored the bottle over the course of the evening, but it didnt last long enough. Next time! 10/5/8/4/17=4.4

08 bottle sampled July 09. Explosive pop of the cork but not much spillage; everything I wrote above (which I had to seriously doubt when I re-read last week) is true. Dang this is a good beer. This is what Angels Share would taste like if it were carbonated.
Unknown date (black label) sampled Nov 13Dark pour, almost completely flat but not completely flat the way other Angels Share has been. Well blended oak, sweeter and a bit less depth than I recall, but still pretty good. Id probably go more like 4.1 or 4.2, but Ill let the original stand as I believe the beer was closer to Tommes intention at that time.

This beer has benefitted from the whiskey barrel aging. Pours brown with no head and a fruit and dark malt aroma. There is a very complex flavor that is enhanced with a very complementary whiskey taste. A marvelous product.
Just a phenomenal beer.  Poured dark brown into a tulip glass at Monks in Philly.  Aromas of burnt wood, vanilla, raisins and dark fruit.  Tastes of sweet vanilla, coffee beans and plums.

Pours very dark brown, with no head. Thickish like a malted milkshake. Some bourbon and chocolate aroma, and voila! it taste like well integrated chocolate and bourbon, neither overpowering the other.Nicley drinkable, its like an aged old imperial stout, and without the booziness apparent. Dangerously drinkable.

2009 bottle, pours dark almost blackish brown with a thin off white film of a head, but there is carbonation!  Nice sweet vanilla, oak, and bourbon nose, with a sour twang.  Flavor is sweet fig and dark burnt sugar with strong bourbon coming into play and a spicey hot whiskey, and grainy finish.  Very interesting and I like it more than the brandy.  Carbonation is light, but there, I dont think it adds or subtracts from this beer.
( 375ml bottle thanks to mar) Pours opaque brown with no head. Nose of brown sugar, wood, alcohol and bourbon. Taste of molasses, caramel and brown sugar. No carbonation. Good but not great.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma consists of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, and faint vinous notes.  It pours orangish-brown with small beige head that quickly fades to a fine ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel.  The finish has moderate maple syrup, vanilla, and faint bourbon.  Medium-full bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel.

375ml bottle, 2009.   Dark brown with almost no head.   Bourbon, dried fruit, soy sauce, wood and caramel in the aroma.   The flavor is smoother and lacks the oxidized soy notes of the aroma.   Lots of dried fruit, tobacco, toasty grain, some chocolate and oak.   Rich and alcoholic but not harsh.   Thick and flat on the tongue.   Great flavor and immensely complex, but the weird oxidized soy notes in aroma and lack of bubbles hurt it overall.
2009 bottle thanks to mar.  poured black with no head.  aroma and flavor were bourbon, cherry, and soy.  no notes on palate.

375ml bottle @Pauls Gathering. Black pour with some head. Its nice to see how good this beer can be with proper carbonation. Great texture,  bunch of flavors that go together well. Aging brings beer together.

Bottle courtesy of Mar.

Pours dark brown with no head. This one is definitely flat. Aroma is a combination of roasted malts and bourbon, with maybe come chocolate and caramel mixed in. The flavor is lots of bourbon, oak and vanilla with some alcohol, roasted malt and chocolate/coffee. A very complex flavor. The mouthfeel is hurt by the fact the beer is flat as a pancake. Still, it is pretty drinkable and a good beer overall. I think it would be better with proper carbonation.
estremaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa!! birra molto complessa ke dovrei riprovare meglio per giudicarla a dovere... impressionanti al naso le noti vanigliate

Sweet malty aroma with toffee and vanilla notes and just a bit of bourbon. No hop character and no off flavors that I could detect. Reddish brown, dark but not completely opaque. I got some of the yeast mixed in so I cant get a good read on clarity. Good level of carbonation, a tan head that lasts and is easily regenerated and good lacing on the glass. Sweet malty toffee and vanilla and a hint of bitterness. Medium to full bodied and sticky with a long warming finish. I like a lot. Its got a great level of complexity and I really enjoy the aroma and flavor. It was a pleasure to drink on an evening thats clear as a bell and cold as hell!

Bottle for rating #2800:   Heavy caramel, deep and dark, somewhat muddy, moderate to large frothy beige head, enjoyable lacing.   Subtle woody nose, soft bourbon, vanilla, raisin, molasses, and graham cracker.   Sweet caramel flavors up front, warming but not alcoholic.   Bourbon and wood characters are more noticeable on the tongue than on the nose.   Not as heavy as I thought, a little spritzy even.   Caramel and toffee notes dominate the backside.   Very little hop bitterness.   Not overly malty either.   Fairly sweet, fairly tasty.   Could stand to be a little bit heavier.   Some minor ash or charred wood on the exit.   Plenty interesting, just wished for more of a viscous mouthfeel versus spritzy.   Yeah, this one seemed carbonated enough.   Tasty!
on tap at uber tavern during new years eve. Obvious touches of oak and bourbon

2008 Bottle from theisti shared with my b-i-l and nephew. Pours murky brown, some floaties, no head whatsoever. Nose is bourbon and a little toasty caramel, raisins and dates. Flavor is the nose - first the bourbon, then some more pronounced sweetness of raisins and brown sugar. Alcohol heat  finishes. Mouthfeel/Palate - as noted many hundreds of times, it was utterly flat. IME - the flavors werent enough to overcome this - it was hard to drink for me, and the flatness accentuated the alcohol and slight astringency.  There was enough good stuff going on to save it from the drain, but not a good effort from LA.

Pours dark brown with no head.   Aroma has a big nose of bourbon and  malt. Tastes of vanilla, wood, bourbon, dried fruit, the finish has a bit of toast on it.  Super smooth texture and the alcohol will sneak up on you.
bottle, thanks to mar, muddy brown pour with raisin, caramel and chocolate aroma and flavor, maybe some roast, seemed off a bit
Rich, sweet, bourbon is not overwhelming. Caramel, maybe a touch of toffee. Strength is obvious, but not too much so.

Bought a 375 mL bottle of 2009 vintage at Lost abbey brewery. Even at the brewery they charge $15 for a 12 oz bottle, but its well worth it because this might be the most delicious beverage ever. is it really a beer?... no carbonation at all and i cant even taste the alcohol. its certainly not a barley wine... way too dark and flat. i agree more with beeradvocate who calls this a strong ale. it tastes like fruit and chocolate and everything about is wonderful.  its really the perfect dessert... especially with some vanilla ice cream. mmmmmmm an angels share float!

10.29.09 750ml bottle.  Pours black with no head/slight rimming.  Aroma strong of bourbon, bitter, malty.  Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, fruity, slight toasty, a bit thin on the tongue.  Intensely dry mouth feel.

375ml bottle poured into a snifter.  Color is deep brown with small tan creamy head that leaves nice lacing and sticks around for a while.  Aroma is mainly of bourbon and oak, with heavy sweet dark bread, molasses, caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit, and vanilla.  Flavor is heavily sweet, with a somewhat dry, long acidic finish.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy, with very fizzy carbonation and an alcohol burn at the end.  Quite a rich and delicious treat!

Nose  is strong of bourbon. Raisin and alcohol. Pours a dark brown. No head at all, In fact, not a single bubble. Flavor like a shot of bourbon. Caramel. Very sweet. Silky smooth on the palate. No carbonation. A fantastic beer. Unfortunately, cannot rate it any higher due to lack of head and no carbonation.

Diverse, intense, different every sip but some how this is still tainted for me in some way. Could have one more layer of excellence with a little more carbonation. 2008 vintage. A little bit of a smoky woody aroma. Vanilla flavors with a bit of cocoa a little further down the palate. Lots of red fruit mid palate and a nice sweetness to round it all out. Caramel, plum, earthy tones, all a little bit in there. Finish is a little hot and a little bittersweet. More like a chocolate than a hop finish.

Bottle courtesy of mar. Very murky brown color. No head whatsoever. Huge whisky smell with roasted notes. Flavor of bourbon and heavy coffee malts. Sharp flavors that linger. A bit of chocolate sits later on. Wow intense.

Pure black color.  Aroma is full of chocolate, vanilla, barley, raisins, and coconut.  Taste is nothing short of amazing.  Youd have to have it to honestly know what Im talking about.  Flavors include chocolate, vanilla, malts and barley, and dark dried fruit.  Has a nice milk chocolaty and vanilla finish with a little bit of dried cherry.  WOW!!! This is one amazing brew!

Bottle: Poured a clear deep brown color ale with a medium foamy head with little to no retention and no lacing. Aroma of bourbon with light vanilla and balanced sweet rich malt. Taste is a well balanced mix between some deep rich English style malt with light dry fruits and with great notes of bourbon and light vanilla. Body is fuller then average with very low carbonation but still enough to be enjoyable with no apparent alcohol which is surprising considering the clear notes of bourbon. Not bad thought not sure it is worth the price tag or should be ion the top 50 but glad I tried it anyway.

Bottle via trade with toncatcher. Deep murky sediment-laden red-brown body, thick, puffy tan head. Nose of prune, soy, and molasses, salty and leathery, with hints of oxidation. Dark fruits (especially raisin and prune) and oak feature prominently in the rich, creamy body, which also features notes of soy and dusty oxidation. Vinous. A complex, rich beer with a dense flavor profile. Although this was a fine beer, I prefer the brandy barrel version.
On tap at Stumbling Monk in Seattle.  Overall, this beer was perfect for a bourbon barrel barleywine.

2007 vintage thanks to the Tampa Tasting Group.  Pours cola brown with a tan head.  Nose is malt, bourbon, brandy, overripe dark fruit, caramel sweetness, and lots of fruity, bourbony, sugary goodness.  Flavor is malt, bourbon, wood, vanilla, dark fruit, caramel, and lots of mellow sweetness.  Balanced for a bourbon beer, yet still boozy.  Medium bodied, sweet finish, and overall pleasure in a bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 2008 (last years) vintage (not the new release). 375ml bottle into DFH snifter.

A - Open with a loud "pop". Poured aggressively so there was a huge head. Black with a frothy tan head that leaves a good amount of lacing behind. The head is very sticky and hangs on to the side of the glass.

S - Dark fruit, boozy bourbon, chocolate. Smells very smooth and complex...a lot more then I can describe in a review. A sweet smell fills the nose after the initial notes fade.

T - Wow. Very good. Plums, raisins, milk chocolate, malts, dark cherry, smooth bourbon flavor. Better then I expected, truthfully. 

M - Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, rich, creamy, smooth. Great to swirl around in your mouth and savor. 

D - Very smooth for the style and barrel aging. Easy to drink, alcohol is smooth and subtle, very smooth. Lost Abby hits a HR on this one. Very good.

2008 Vintage
10/29/2009:  Lost Abbey Angels Share (Bourbon)... Aroma:  Wet wood; cherry and nuts (roasted almond?); caramel/toffee malts; slight green apple (but not enough to be distracting).
